I just read a case for Civil Procedure in which I found myself agreeing with then-Justice (now Chief Justice) Rehnquist. Against the likes of Brennan and Marshall, two all-stars of the Supreme Court if there ever were! Law school makes us do strange things. No worries, though, it wasn't on some key moral issue, just the contacts needed for a state to apply its own laws instead of the laws of the state where an accident occurred. Like you know what that means! ;-)

Meanwhile, in NBC's alternate (better) reality, President Bartlett kicked ass tonight. It's really a shame that none of our current politicians can think on their feet as fast as he portrays. Obviously they don't have multiple takes to get things right, but I can still yearn. And then there's our current President, who couldn't find a coherent thought if you stapled one to his forehead. Anyway, still have a little Civ Pro to read tonight, and maybe some Torts if I feel like. The beauty of Torts is, no matter what I read I won't be able to use it if Ursin asks me any questions. We'll also find out if I did well on the practice midterm in Torts. A day of wonder!
I now have it on good urlLink authority that's it's not only fun to look at women's breasts, it's informative! Those crazy Japanese are at it again. Oh to be a scientist in Tokyo...

Have you ever noticed that television and movies portray law students as pompous bastards? On CSI tonight, the police were holding a bunch of people, and of course Mr. Law Student (Third Year Version) says "Hey I'm a Third Year Law Student (of course), and I know you can't hold us like this." Yeah, he's right, but you know what? When some kid is murdered and the cops are holding everyone from nearby, 99 out of 100 law students will sit dutifully by and cooperate. So nuts to you, CSI, and all other shows that make me feel like a jerk for being in law school. There's another whole issue here concerning the disparagement of the law profession in general. But I'm sure every first-year law student tries to heroically defend his or her chosen profession, so I won't belabor the point right now. But I'm on to you, Hollywood. ;-)

I'm moving to Minnesota and voting for urlLink Mondale as a tribute to Sen. Wellstone. He really was a pioneer, and a wacky liberal like me could usually count on him to do the right thing. That was so rare in public office, among both parties. He will be sorely missed.

Now I gotta say, I think urlLink this is just about the lamest thing I've ever heard of. For those of you too lazy to click the link, it's basically a company that's offering websites a way "around" pop-up ad blockers. About a month ago I finally installed one of those blockers (and it's pretty good, I think I might have mentioned it in here but if not you can get it at urlLink www.panicware.com ) and it's been great. Now this guy says it's actually theft! Theft, he says! He must have the same brilliant gift for analysis that the guy who said "fast forwarding through commercials is theft." Look, pop-up ads suck. EVERYONE hates them, especially the ones that spawn over and over again. I'm also annoyed by those interstitials (ads that play right on the page, blocking the content) but pop-ups are far worse. The idea that we shouldn't be allowed to stop ads from opening new browser windows is absurd; you could make an equally compelling (and by compelling I mean absurd and flimsy) argument that causing pop-up ads is a breach of security and privacy. I control my computer, and I control what I want my web browser to do. If someone tries to hijack my machine, you can damn well bet I'm not visiting that site again. Yeah, so basically shut the hell up. "Anti-theft" my ass. This company pretty much sucks all around, also promoting source-code blocking tools and tools that keep users from "undesirable" countries from accessing their clients' web sites. I won't even get into why those are extraordinarily under-handed tricks.

Well that was just a big mess yesterday, wasn't it? I've already changed my mind about who's fault this is. It's no longer the stupidity of the vast, uninformed American public (though they never help things). It's the Democrats. Am I traveling in the wrong circles? Why is everyone I know fairly-to-very liberal? And yet the Democrats are moving towards the center. They're no longer progressive, as a party, nor are they even very interesting anymore. They're a weak and pathetic imitation of the Republican party, who, god bless 'em, at least have the chutzpah to stand up for what they believe in. I may fight them to the death on almost every issue, but at least they don't equivocate their thoughts away like the D's. Yes, the Democrats were scared. I would have been too, holding a tiny majority that represents their last real vestige of power in the Federal Government. Now, because they were so chicken-shit in this election, they've lost everything Clinton put together. They've been too eager to say "well I'm not against insert conservative issue , but I think we need to be smart about it." Goddammit, I want you to be AGAINST an overly-broad interpretation of the 2nd Amendment. I want you to be AGAINST allowing God into government. I want you to be AGAINST pollution of the environment. And yet, Democrats cave. They give in, show off their hunting rifles and talk about how important God and their SUV are in their lives. They've lost my vote for now, and unless a Democrat comes along with a better theme than "the party that's a little less rigid than the GOP", I'm voting Green. Oh, and the worst part? The implications this may have on the Supreme Court. You better pray that Rehnquist and O'Connor stay healthy. One thing law school has taught me is the power of the Supremes, and boy howdy will they wreak havoc if the Court is stacked with conservatives.

Blarg! The stupid Republicans are going to pull this off, aren't they? You know, the only thing saving this country from its own completely inept leadership was the tiny Democratic majority in the Senate. If that's gone... I am literally weak from fear right now. Or maybe I'm weak from eating two peanut butter & jelly sandwiches for dinner. Nothin' like home cookin! A pox! A pox on the Bush administration's disastrous effects on our nation.

I don't know if I mentioned this before, but law school textbooks refer to all hypothetical people with female pronouns. That is, if X and Y are fighting and X kills Y with a fork, she is guilty of homicide. It's always she or her. I'm not exactly sure why that is, except maybe that it's an attempt at avoiding sexist writing by always having female hypothetical actors. But the end result is strange, because when the situation calls for 2 different genders, but only one of the participants is guilty of a crime, it's always the woman. Only in the Land of Law School Textbooks are women more likely to kill their husbands, rob banks, or generally cause mayhem. None of that holds true when it comes to rape, however, which makes sense I suppose since traditional rape laws don't involve anything but female victims. Anyway, just thought that was weird enough to point out. On the upside, it makes it easier to remember weird hypothetical situations, because when I read "he" I just think "person" but when I read "she" I think "a woman did THAT?" Maybe I'm a sexist bastard.

I've decided that I'm not sure I can focus on one thing at a time very well. I don't mean on a small scale (like a book) but in the big picture, like "law school" or "a social life" or "a part time job" or whathaveyou. Even though I've decided that my social life should (and pretty much is) taking a back seat to law school, that's maybe 25% my doing and 75% just-the-way-it-is. I'd like to take credit for being focused, but the truth is that in its spare moments, my mind is concentrating on everything BUT law school. So why can't I just focus? I don't even WANT a social life at this point, but I can't stop my stupid brain from thinking about it. Perhaps it's simply a matter of discipline, of denying myself the social contacts that keep those thoughts alive. I don't go out much as it is, but maybe it's time I completely shut down that part of my brain. On the other hand, who likes a guy who cares about nothing but his work? Answer: nobody. And I don't mean that in a "I want to be liked way" but more in a "I want to be happy with myself" way, and I'm pretty sure I'd get really sick of me like that. I think I have a lot to sort out about myself these days. Trying to figure out just how much of my personality is (and should be) devoted to hard work and life goals, and how much is devoted to living life to the fullest right now. Because as I see it, the two aren't coexisting very well. Also I'm out of milk. I hate that. And I'll be damned if I'm going out again tonight. It's already 5:30 and I'm exhausted.

It's basically true that unless they become a real bastard or something, you never stop loving someone. Fortunately for me, I'm a real bastard so I'm pretty sure that my own "string of broken hearts" will in reality be a "string of really pissed off women". But you can love someone and know that they don't belong in your life right now, and it's one of the hardest things to admit. Someone smart recently told me: "Meeting the right girl is only half the battle. Meeting her at the right time will complete the picture. Meeting her at the wrong time only ends in the pain of what might have been." People think that if you try hard enough, or want it bad enough, you can create the "right time" but that's not true. And now I know exactly what that feels like, so if anyone ever has any questions or wonders if that's whats happening in their relationships, just ask me. I'll give you a gut-wrenching description of how it feels to be at the wrong time.
Sometimes life is as hard as a diamond, and there's nothing you can do but grit your teeth and let it tear you up.

The Fourth Amendment prohibition against unreasonable searches and seizures is one of the fundamental rights guaranteed to every citizen of the United States. (U.S. Const. amend. IV.) These rights, like many others, can be waived and consent to search can be granted. The consent to search a residence, however, can only be given by a person with actual or apparent authority to consent. The case at hand concerns the ability of a third party to consent to a search when, although the third party lacked actual authority, apparent authority to consent existed. (this is what i will be writing for the next 36 hours)

I'm really way to neurotic for any woman to ever put up with me for more than a few weeks, at least in a relationship. I have no idea how Kim did it; maybe I wasn't neurotic in the beginning or something, and so when I did go insane it was already well into the 'ship. Frankly, if I met someone like me (well, except female) I'd probably lose my mind after 1 week of dating. Perhaps the key is to not date anybody you actually care about. That way, you don't get neurotic because you don't worry very much because you don't care. That doesn't seem very interesting, though. Maybe that's why people meet first and then fall in love, instead of falling in love and then getting together. Because if you think about it, falling in love first puts everything right up at the beginning. There's all this emotion running rampant, and you're trying to get a relationship off the ground at the same time. Plus, doing it that way makes the pressure to succeed so much greater. On the other hand, if you barely know the person and just started going out because they seemed interesting, there's plenty of time to endear yourself before all those pain in the ass neuroses make their entrance. Maybe that's how Kim put up with me - we weren't in love right from the get-go. And only after we actually started caring about each other did it become worthwhile to put up with all the crap we gave each other. So, in conclusion, no more dating friends. I like my friends too much to put any of them through that. I really don't know why reading about interpleading and subrogation of third-party claims led to this. Me + Law = strange relationship, man.

Okay, so that personality test was not a hit with anyone. Maybe it's NOT accurate, I'm hardly a psychologist. It told me fairly positive things, and in those categories that I scored "Below Average" I was in agreement. For those who are taking the test and getting poor results, I would make two disclaimers: 1. Your state of mind when filling out those little rankings is pretty key. If you're in, say, a horrible mood then yeah the test will reflect that. Take it again when you're cheerful and see if the results come out differently. 2. Make sure you read the responses carefully - the test details only mention a couple of categories (i.e. "People who score Above Average are...") - but not specifically the category you may have fallen into. I think "negative perfectionism" isn't all that bad anyway. Nobody likes cocky people. Overall these tests are like horoscopes; you see what you want to see, pick out the parts that seem to coincide with your own self-image, and toss out the rest. The results aren't meant to be a laundry list of specific personal problems; just possible problems that could someday arise. In other news, interesting discussions with the kids at lunch about jealousy and what it means to a relationship. I was always of the opinion that jealousy reared its ugly head when deeper emotions came into play; nobody cares that much when someone you barely like acts to provoke jealousy. But perhaps jealousy is just a tool that people use to mask their true feelings about their own inadequacies and fears. I've never known anyone to be jealous of anything I do, simply because there aren't that many people who give a rat's ass about what I do. So it's hard for me to approach it with both experiences in mind (being jealous and being the subject of jealousy), but I still think that it's a natural emotion that shouldn't be completely crapped on. Only when it's used to hurt, or to destroy trust, or to otherwise compromise a perfectly healthy relationship does jealousy become harmful. Sermonizing off. urlLink Who are you? This online personality test is unlike most others on the web, i.e. it's very technical in nature and probably far more accurate than "HOW KEWL R U?!?" at The Spark or something. Not that I don't love the Spark, I'm just saying. Anyway, if you can decipher the fairly complex results (be sure to hit the Info button at the bottom of the first results page) you might find that it does a pretty good job of nailing strengths and weaknesses. Hell, it told me I have self-esteem difficulties, and anybody who knows me probably knows that's my biggest personal issue. Besides all the heroin. I use humor as a defense mechanism. ;-) My biggest fear these days is that I'm manic depressive, except perhaps it's a very mild case. Some days I'm just like "bring it on world!! yeah!" and then the very next day I feel like it's all a bunch of crap. That could also be just the way law school works, so I'm not too worried. While I'm (not) on the subject, here's a weird thing: people only tell me about the bad parts of their lives. Actually that might not just be me, maybe it's general human nature. But I've noticed that alot of the opinions I have of other people are improperly slanted towards the negative. I don't mean people I actually know , but more like people they tell me about. Friends, roommates, boyfriends, girlfriends, parents - everyone complains, I suppose that's natural. But then people get surprised when I have a slightly negative opinion, like it came out of nowhere. I saw this problem with Kim and her mom a few times. She'd tell me all that bad, horrible, mean crap that her mom does, and then she'd be surprised at how much I disliked her mom. But when all you hear about is the bad stuff, how are you supposed to form a full opinion? Granted, after I met her mom and such, my antipathy slacked off, but it's an awkward position to be in, meeting someone for the first time and already having a negative opinion. Currently the same thing goes for Cindy's boyfriend, who by all objective accounts seems like a perfectly nice guy. But since she always seems annoyed or frustrated, or talks about how she's 3 seconds away from dropping him completely, I tend to go that way as well. After all, I don't know him, but I know her, and my natural inclination is to sympathize and support. But now I feel bad because there seems to be a general impression that I dislike him, which is unfair to both of us because we've never even met. So to conclude, I blame you people for not sharing the happy parts of your relationships with me. If I'm a bitter old man who hates everyone except my close friends, it's all your faults. ;-) Okay not all, but share a little love sometime!

Well here's a sad day for space exploration. The more I think about it, though, the more it seems apparent that this isn't terrbly surprising. It's sad, horribly sad, but I read somewhere once that because of the complicated nature of spaceflight, odds are 1 in 75 that something will go wrong. That's staggeringly high when you consider that "something going wrong" is pretty much equal to death for everyone. There's no "we barely survived" at 13,000 mph. Thus, as it has been reported, the astronauts all know about the bad odds when they go into this, and I look at it as a job akin to voluntarily joining one of the armed forces. Yes, it's sad when they die too, but you know what? It's part of the job. I don't mean for that to sound as cold as perhaps it does, because I really and truly am sad at both the loss of life and the implications this may have for stifling future exploration. But I don't think the astronauts themselves would be as sad as the public, since they know the risks, and the reward - travelling beyond our planet - is worth it. That's courageous and worthy of our respect and admiration. I'm glad it's not terrorists, but now that it's all been established I don't want to watch the news anymore. MTV and the Travel Channel today, because everything the news reports from this point on will be crappy conjecture; it will take NASA & Co. months to determine the precise causes of the accident, so Brian Williams and company can just sit on it for a while. They won't because that's not how news goes these days, but it's frustrating to see so much non-news being reported. Anyway, back to outlining for Property. I think I'm going to a Chinese New Year party tonight, which should be cool or very awkward since I don't know anybody. Once more into the breach!

So what do you do when someone you care about is unhappy? You help them in whatever way you can. But what do you when their unhappiness is largely (though not entirely) as a result of things that you did? That's a stumper. You can't fix it, you can't apologize enough, you basically can't do anything except step out of the action for awhile, and hope that they figure out how to fix it themselves. It's frustrating to no end, to know that it's not just that you CHOOSE not to do something to help, but that literally there is nothing in the world that you yourself can do that would provide any comfort. Perhaps that's not entirely your fault, though - if someone is in pain because of something you did, but they refuse to help themselves and instead just decide that the universe is against them, there's really nothing you can do except feel bad and then move on. People can't get better if they don't allow themselves to do so. Maybe everyone just has bad days. It sure seems like there's a general funk in the air these days - and not the good, P-Funk kind. More like a man-is-this-all-there-is kind of thing. I see it in my friends both here and back home, to varying degrees. I can see where the law school people get it, because I'm in that. And others may be having job troubles or relationship problems (or both), or be like me where you have all 3 in a big mixed bag of crap. But maybe it's just the "spring gloom" or something. Winter is pretty much finished, but the warmth of summer isn't here and even in San Diego the days can be pretty gloomy. Or maybe it's just Monday, which at last count was hated by approximately every human being on the planet.

You know that joke that involves the law firm of "Dewey, Cheatem, and Howe"? Well don't ever tell it. It's a lame, lame joke and it's not funny. You should especially not tell it around lawyers, who fully believe it's a lame joke and will not laugh. If they do laugh, they're only being kind, like when you laugh at a joke that a 6-year-old made up. Unless it's a funny 6-year-old. It's the kind of lame joke that my dad would tell, except that's being to harsh on my dad, who despite his penchant for bad jokes (asking the waiter if the restaurant "do you all take Mobil? haha!") probably wouldn't use the Dewey punchline. So do yourselves a favor, faithful readers, and expunge that particular punchline from your memory banks. Another good rule is, don't tell jokes of a certain category to a person in that category, unless you're REALLY sure it's new and they haven't heard it. And that they have a sense of humor. Examples: telling blondes Blonde Jokes, telling lawyers Lawyer Jokes, telling priests Pope Jokes. The list goes on. You also want to avoid telling Pollack Jokes to Polish people, and in general don't ever make a joke about a person's name, because they've heard that before. No matter how witty you think you are (you're not) they've heard it before. Trust me. Just doing my part to make comedy more sophisticated.

That saying that "50% of all marriages end in divorce" is inaccurate. The only way you get that is if you take the number of marriages in a year (say 100,000) as compared to the number of divorces (50,000). Yes, that's half, but it's not half of the people who just got married. Those 50,000 divorces come from the gigantic pool of already married people, which is much larger. So technically, if the trend continues for a very long time (multiple generations) then yeah that will be the result. But right now it's really just a statistic that people use to scare other people. I just thought I'd toss that out there. I've heard that particular phrase maybe 3 times just today, so I figured it warranted comment. Especially since nothing else interesting happened.

So, today in Property we discussed "common interest communities", which are basically the gated communities that have a load of rules about what you can and can't do with your property. When you buy a house in these communities, you sign a deed which says you will abide by the restrictions put forth by the Homeowner's Association. Then everybody gets to live in a nice neighborhood where none of the houses are painted in eye-watering shades of purple and nobody has junked cars on their lawns. Because if they do those things, they'll be heavily fined by the HOA. So the question in class was, what restrictions should be allowable? The current state of the law is that most courts give a great deal of deference to the restrictions that exist, and a rule will need to be grossly unreasonable or against public policy to be struck down. I was just incensed at the entire idea of "common interest communities", to be perfectly honest. There is a tension between freedom to do what you want (within the boundaries of the law) and freedom to associate with who you want (which may necessitate an abridgement of your constitutional rights). My personal opinion is that restrictions for planned communities are a load of crap. When you purchase a house, and own the property in fee simple (that just means own it outright, no strings attached) you should be able to do whatever you like with the house and the land within the bounds of the government's laws, NOT within the bounds of some randomly chosen association bylaws. There's a reason we allow government to create and maintain laws - government has the resources and the bureacracy to do so. If a law is no good, then the courts will strike it down, or it will be vetoed by another branch, or it will be overruled by another law from the law-making body. Where are these protections in the tiny little planned community dictatorships? There are no courts, there is no executive branch; sure the people on the Board are elected by the residents of the community, but is that enough lip service to the democratic process to allow the hugely unconstitutional restrictions those Boards then apply? I say no. And another thing (since I'm ranting): one of the basic attributes of the human condition is that we will interact and share ideas with one another, thus hopefully learning and improving our collective lives. But if you insulate yourself into a hegemonic community of people who only think and act a specific way (and they have to, because otherwise they'll be heavily fined or even have their house taken away) how much are you contributing to the ideal of positive human interaction? I want to live near the crazy old man who doesn't mow his lawn very often, and the weird couple that put out pink flamingos on their lawn, and the even weirder old woman who puts up so many Christmas lights in December that 747s mistake the street for an emergency runway. I know that lowers property values; and maybe some people want to live in an idyllic utopia of perfectly manicured lawns and absolutely no individuality. But those people, in the end, are missing out on the cultural experiences that come with living in a community of mixed personalities. /end sermon. Whew. Although here's a necessary postscript: I don't think HOA's that deal with common areas, like a common pool or park or trash service or other such things, is a bad idea. In fact I think that's a good idea, because then everyone can have the benefit of such things without having to buy them themselves. It's when the powers of the HOA cross over into restrictions on personal property that I begin to take issue.

Have you ever had a friend that, after awhile, you couldn't figure out why they were your friend? Not so much that you don't like him or her, but that you can't see why him or her bothers hanging out with you, when they don't seem to respect or care about anything you say or think. I think the phrase "absence makes the heart grow fonder" can apply to friendships just as easily as to other relationships. It can be very easy to take people for granted, I know I have in the past, but I also think I'm especially easy to take for granted because I'm generally very easy-going and non-confrontational. It's dumb to purposely avoid people you consider a friend, but at the same time it's depressing to think that a friend finds nothing you say even remotely interesting. On the other hand, maybe that's why you have good friends. You're supposed to be able to take them for granted sometimes, to know that they'll be there for you even when you're focus is somewhere completely different. It may be only when it becomes an established trend that it's time to seriously question the friendship. I know some people who have stuck by their "friend" even when that friend was anything but (and for a long time, too) simply because they had such a long history. But just giving someone space isn't "questioning" the friendship, so maybe that's a positive first step. It's not a test to see if they'll notice (because you shouldn't "test" your friends like that) but rather breathing room that probably both people need. It seems like life is really just a serious of interpersonal relationships, and men and women simply bounce from person to person. It's how many people define themselves and the phases of their lives - especially after school is over. When you're in highschool, college, and if applicable, grad school, you tend to think of your life in those chunks. But afterwards, life becomes more defined by your job and those you associate with. Not necessarily intimate relationships only, but every kind - business, friendship, family. I think that's the best way to live. Your life can be your job, but eventually you will need more. Right now I'm in the thick of continuing my education, and so I look at my life more in terms of semesters. But I could also define it by my friends: who has come into my life, who has dropped out, and who has seen their status change (from friend to "more", or vice versa). It's an interesting way to view things - sort of like putting your records in autobiographical order instead of alphabetical. I think I'm going to go watch "High Fidelity" again.

The current state of copyright bothers me intensely. Most notably, the enormous (and expanding) time limit that authors/artists enjoy. The original purpose behind copyright was to ensure authors and musicians the royalties from their creations for their lifetimes . Thanks to lobbying efforts, primarily from Disney and other large media conglomerates, that time limit (somewhere between 14 and 28 years) has been expanded to a grossly unfair 70 years . Unless you write a book when you're five years old, it is unlikely that any author will even come even close to outliving his or her works. So why is Disney pushing (and very close to getting) another extension to 150 years? For the obvious reason: Disney isn't going anywhere, and Disney holds thousands of copyrights. Perhaps the founding fathers didn't foresee the development of essentially immortal copyright holders. The entire purpose behind copyright (in my opinion, that is) is to give authors an incentive for creation while limiting the inheritability of such creations. Aside from strange contractual obligations, copyright is one of the only areas where the heirs of a "creator" hold so much power. We don't let the children of CEO's simply slide into the seat when their parent dies; we don't give professional athletes' kids a spot on the roster simply because the athlete died before his 70 year contract was over. The heirs will argue that they should be allowed to reap the profits of the ancestors, but they already do - they get the estate money just like the rest of us. Unlike the rest of us, however, copyright heirs also get the rights to new publications of books and music written long, long ago. Publications they had no part in creating or developing whatsoever. This is because of the spectacularly lame 70 year protection. If copyright were only for 30 years, then after that time the works become public domain and nobody has to pay to reprint them. That's why the works of Charles Dickens are reprinted by 12 different publishing companies every year - they don't have to ask for permission anymore. Maybe therein lies my problem with copyright. Music and books are, to a high degree, intangible commodities at the core. Sure, you can go buy a book, but what you're paying for are the ideas and stories within. Once you read that, you could tell those stories to whoever you wanted. And unlike other commodities (like oil, lumber, or nerf footballs) the using of the commodity doesn't take anything away from the original. 10 people can read one book, and all have shared in the commodity without detracting from the book itself. A million people could - but if a million people tap an oil deposit, the deposit will soon run dry. With this in mind, it seems absurd to try to restrict use of such intellectual property beyond a reasonable period for recoupment of expenses by the creator. If your book is wildly popular, then you'll make a mint and your kids can see some of that someday. But instead of allowing your children to rest on your laurels until the end of time, a limited copyright would give authors a much stronger incentive to create something new. Stephen King would be exactly as rich today under a 30 year copyright as he is under a 70 year copyright. The difference lies in how rich his children's children will be in 50 years. And in my socialist-leaning view, they shouldn't get squat for the creativity of their long gone ancestors. This may be why I'm a huge fan of the so-called "death tax" as well, but that's a post for another day. :) Oh, urlLink here's what set me off in the first place.

So, sometimes I'm too opinionated about certain things. Well, scratch that, I'm opinionated about many things. As a general rule, I try not to theorize about things I have no experience with, and I think that has generally worked out well. There is a flip side, however, because although some people (friends, family, etc.) have realized that most of what I say is just an opinion, there are others who, although I consider them dear friends, haven't picked up on that exactly. Sometimes what I say is seen as preachy, or patronizing, or even like I'm giving orders. Although I don't believe it has ever been my intention to actually preach, patronize, or order, I have also been of the opinion that "if you can't see that, that's not my fault." Well, it's time for a change. I have a number of dear friends that, although we see eye-to-eye 90% of the time, they misunderstand when I disagree with them on the other 10%. And although I do believe I am both entitled to my opinion and within my rights to express it, it is also my responsibility to keep misunderstandings to a minimum. Therefore I will be making a conscious, concerted effort to keep my opinions to myself unless expressly asked for. Because even though I think part of being friends, especially good friends, is sharing what you think, if that sharing is misunderstood then it is more of a burden than a benefit (oops, a little Property snuck in there). Of course this doesn't mean I expect others to refrain from giving opinions; I hope most people will continue to do so because I have always felt quite blessed to have the input of so many very intelligent and observant people. But until I can find a way to return the favor without offending, that'll be a one-way street. Civ Pro Final in... 9 1/2 hours! Keep those fingers crossed for me.

There's an interesting split between those who believe the judicial system exists to provide justice, and those who believe it exists to enforce the law as written. Jaime was reading a book today called "Justice v. Law" that brought up a case directly on that point. Those who believe in justice feel that courts should bend, stretch and, when necessary for justice to be served, even break the rules that have been set by the legislature. Those who believe in law are stricter in their reading of statute and rule, and feel that legislature should craft the law and the judiciary should simply interpret those rules and apply them to particular situations. The difference between the two sides are at once both eerily similar and starkly different. While this may sound all well and good, most law students and many people can tell you the law and justice do not commonly meet in the same place. While it may be "the law" that a father who shoots his child's murderer is himself a murderer, justice often tells us the opposite. That's why there are many exceptions and nuances to law, quirks that afford people like the vengeful father a chance at a reduced sentence. For while we cannot completely condone such actions, there are loopholes and procedural rules that a judge can choose to follow strictly or leniently, depending on where the judge's sense of "justice" falls. The second problem is for every definition of "justice" there are a million others that are slightly or even drastically different. Whose definition do we follow? Are there really some issues on which justice is clear, or is clarity only a cover for the majority opinion? We find the same problem in defining what is moral. This is one of the reasons that, at least in my opinion, the law should be followed over the concerns of justice. While this may seem offensive at first, it must be remembered that the law is crafted to serve the interests of justice. Unfortunately, this requires a degree of faith in those who craft the law, and in these trying times our faith in those may be sorely tested and waning. Of course, I don't have a solution or anything, but I wanted to lay that out for my own brain's sake. I could be horribly wrong, it has been known to happen. Still cloudy out in San Diego! I would really like the summer to come back. I think next summer I'll try and take a month-long break in June and go to Miami.

I was chatting with a urlLink friend who is a waitress last night, and it occurred to me that most guys have no idea how to correctly act when interested in Your Server This Evening. So, here you go: How to Ask Out Waitresses The biggest thing to remember is that inherently, wait-people don't like you. I don't care how nice you are and how nice they seem, they're at work and they'd rather not be, just like the rest of us. You may be having fun with your friends, but your waitress is trying to make enough money to pay the rent next week. Thus, the first (and most obvious) rule is Tip Well. Even if you don't want to go out with your waitress, tip her well. If you don't, she may mention that to the hot waitress you DO want to hook up with, and that'll put the kibosh on your plan. Anyway, after that it's a matter of patience. Become a regular so that she knows your name, and after a friendly interaction has been established (friendly is key - if you're a regular asshole, or a regular drunk who gives her trouble, being "regular" isn't that helpful) wait for a night that A) you know she's working and B) will be slow. Then, and really ONLY then, do you have a shot at success. There are exceptions, of course, and the mathematical equation is that Your Attractiveness is inversely proportional to Time You Must Wait. So if you're Brad Pitt, go ahead and ask her out the first time you visit. But if you're Joe Shmoe, you'd better wait. There are other alternate strategies as well, like going back at closing time which could be seen either as sweet (that you'd come back) or scary (you stalker freak). It's a gamble. Also, this theory is sort of applicable to other service-oriented professions. Adjust where necessary. Next week: The Perils of Online Dating.

In the past few days/weeks, I have found myself saying things that should more appropriately come out of urlLink my father's mouth. None of them are sayings or acts unique to my father; I expect many people out there have fathers that do them. At dinner, I said "No, don't get dessert, I have plenty to eat back at my place." When driving, I suspect I channel all Bristol males when I give other motorists "tips" on how they could better utilize their vehicles on the open road. The whole situation gives me the heebie-jeebies, and not because he would be a bad person to transform into. My first day off! I have no class on Thursdays (and only one tomorrow) so it's nice to wind the week down this way. So, my Communications Law & Policy class is very interesting, to me, but it's the first time I've been in a class in law school where the "Know-It-All" contingent has made a showing. These are the people that in a technology-oriented (or even just related) class, cannot help correcting the professor or injecting "helpful" facts into the discussion. I find this annoying. I believe it's a by-product of two things: the social ineptitude of many who have worked in the technology sector, and the rapidly evolving nature of technology itself. Because of the speed at which technology advances, it's very hard for any teacher to ever stay completely on top of every development. It's much easier for a student who studies the field simply out of interest. The end result is when the professor says (merely giving an example - none of this is testable material) that AT&T broke up in 1983, someone immediately (and usually without even raising their hand, which is another issue) says "Actually I think it was 1984." Of course that doesn't matter at all to the professor's example, but it gives the geeks a chance to show their prowess in the area. This may only be impressive to other geeks, but speaking for the group I can honestly say it just annoys the crap out of me. In general, this doesn't happen much in law school because unlike some undergrad teachers, every professor is far more informed about their field than any possible student. But add a little something about the Internet, or computers, and all of a sudden a geeky minority feels emboldened to add their unimportant and irrelevant 2 cents. And that's my 2 cents! But notice I didn't subject an entire class to it. That would have been lame.

I often wonder if perhaps there is an "ivory tower" mentality in America today. I'm usually very surprised at the number of people who support things like Justice Moore's stand regarding the urlLink 10 Commandments (link goes to Marek's page, in which he sums up the issue better than I could). Then, after my surprise wears off, I remember that there are numerous "unenlightened" people in this country, people that neither want nor accept the views of those on the coasts. Is it better this way? Is it better that the handful of people in universities, in the media, and in politics rule what is undoubtedly a much larger contingent of people in the "fly-over states"? Most of those who rule are smart, and though they are not all of the same idealogical cloth, they advance their particular views articulately and with passion (Ann Coulter notwithstanding). But should those who are focused on "lesser" things, such as jobs and kids and making dinner, be without representation? Does anybody really speak for them, or is it, as I suspect, merely a parade of politicians who claim to represent the vast middle majority but who in reality do no such thing? On the other hand, maybe I make no sense. It's difficult to grasp the thought process behind much of our creationism-seeking, bible-thumping, salt of the earth brethren. And perhaps in trying to do so I seem patronizing, which I probably am, but not on purpose. It seems to me that the older people get, the more reasons they have to promote their own self-interest. Marriage, and kids, seem to transform once liberal people into much more self-serving individuals. Can you blame them for that? Who doesn't want their kids to go to the best school, have the best clothes, and receive the best opportunities? The NIMBY response ("not in my backyard") does not have to apply only to power stations and municipal waste dumps; it can also apply to kids and family, almost in reverse. Parents who oppose a school voucher system on principle may have dire need for vouchers for their own kids. Families that once despised tax cuts for the rich may find themselves in that category and now strongly favor them. Does this happen to everyone, and will it happen to me? It's situations like urlLink this that really point out how insane copyright law is in this country. I'm not a huge fan of Eminem, but he should be able to use a 24 second bit of music in an otherwise wholly original piece of music without being sued. Why is he sued? Because some woman inherited the rights to that bit of music when her husband died 15 years ago. The music itself was composed 33 years ago for a movie. First: I have no doubt that the deceased composer was paid for his efforts in creating the music. Second: He's dead, and clearly does not need any residual royalties. Third: Even if he wasn't dead, he was already paid for it. At this point, I'm pretty sure that copyright should be limited to something tiny, like 15 or 20 years. I've heard some say 5, but even to my flaming liberal mind that seems too small. The entire point of copyright is to give a creator a monopoly on profit from his or her creation; this is justified (normally we hate monopolies in America) by forcing the creation into the public domain after a specific period of time has passed. Congress has broken that agreement, however, by allowing not 20, not 50, but 70 years of protection after the author has died . This is insane, and there is absolutely no reason why a great artist's work, like the recently passed Johnny Cash, should not become publicly available within the next decade. What is the use in keeping Cash's songs restricted until 2073? Simply so that the license holder can make money, at the expense of the public good. I don't care what I write, or compose, or program in the next year - it should be free to anyone who wants it by 2023 at the latest. I have yet to hear a compelling argument to the contrary, so if anyone has one, step on up to the plate.

Behold the pale horse. The man who sat on him was death, and Hell followed with him. Death is inevitable. There are some who devote significant portions of their life towards fighting against it, but it is the one constant in our existence (you don't have to pay taxes if you don't want to). It sometimes strikes me as amazing that throughout the history of mankind, the only thing that every single human has in common with every other human is that he or she will die. I don't mean any of this to sound depressing, or even fatalistic. I see the inevitability of the future as a challenge, a test of how much living one person can cram into their life. Immortality is only fascinating because we're not immortal, because we can easily conceive of living 10 lifetimes but will not, no matter how hard we try, be allowed to do so. Of course, that's assuming that like me, you don't believe in reincarnation. I don't know exactly what I believe lies in waiting for us when we enter that long dark sleep - maybe that's all it really is. Nothingness is a scary idea, to those who are conscious. But how much does the idea of nothingness scare you when you're unconscious? Isn't it strange that the idea of oblivion is much scarier than oblivion itself, which because of the very nature of the idea, means you can't really "experience" it. I suppose that death might bring a sort of "half-nothing, half-consciousness" whereby we can still perceive and think, but have nothing to perceive or think about. Now that is a scary proposition - trapped in a featureless void for eternity, with only your thoughts as companions. The good news is, that seems highly unlikely. If there is a creator or higher being, I'm sure it wouldn't put all this together just to strand everyone in hell for eternity. And if there isn't a God, then biologically speaking at death we should all simply lose consciousness, and that's that. And that's not so bad, because it's not like you'll know you're dead. The finality of death on one's own consciousness is the most severe event a person can experience, I think. There is no coming back from that, and given the nature of sentience (we're all alone/existence is only in your mind/etc.), every person's death is the complete annihilation of an entire universe - the universe created in and by your brain. No wonder we're not rushing towards it. Even though we all know death isn't the end of everything (because we're not dead, and others are, and we're still here), on an individual level it is the end of the world, as far as the dead guy is concerned. So what's my point? I'm not afraid of death. I don't know how original or unique that is (probably not at all), but at some point in the past 10 years, I reached a certain clarity concerning my own demise. I'm not exactly in a hurry to get there, but when it happens it's not like I'll know, or will be able to sit around saying "Well that sucked. Now I'm dead!" And if I can do that, well hey that sounds like a pretty sweet deal too. This doesn't mean I'm fearless by any stretch of the imagination. I'd rather not get shot, stabbed, or run over by a bus. I'd rather not get a debilitating illness, or be sent to the electric chair. But those are simply means to an end, and while the means are avoidable, the end is not. Or, maybe when you die you end up in Tucson, AZ, for eternity. It's not like I know.

Public Service Announcement: Don't ever, ever try to represent yourself in criminal court without a lawyer. Ever. No matter how smart you think you are, no matter how many years of post-graduate education you might have - hell even if you ARE a lawyer, it's not a good idea. People who represent themselves pro se (without an attorney) are basically putting up no viable defense. It's almost a waste of a court's time, because pleading guilty would probably get you to the same result, only much faster and more eloquently. It's not that you're stupid, or lack the abilities to follow the court proceedings (though most defendants who go pro se are, in fact, morons), it's just that lawyers have far more training than you do. It would be like asking to remove your own gall bladder, or pilot your own Delta flight to Newark. Just because you watch ER every week and have seen Top Gun 32 times, doesn't mean you're qualified to actually do those things. And thus, watching Law & Order or reading John Grisham books likewise has the same effect. The only difference is, our judicial system will actually let you try if you really want to (and you're mentally competent). That's a little bit crazy, if you ask me. And you're more than a little bit crazy if you put your freedom in your own hands. As noble as it may sound, take it from someone who knows - the judicial system is far too complicated to be successfully navigated by a layman. (This message brought to you by urlLink John Allen Muhammad , who made the first correct decision in years this morning by rehiring his attorneys) ps. urlLink Elliot Smith ? What the hell, man? Sam Bitches About the Weather #9,301 We're havin a heat wave, a tropical heat wave. Not quite tropical, but it gives me something to blog about momentarily. Tonight I was out driving around (for fast food, because the grocery store strike is keeping me away from buying cookable food - but that's a separate story) and it was just about 6:30. The sun had set, and the air had taken on that cool, twilight-induced feeling that comes in San Diego after an especially hot day. There's just something about that time of day - it's one of my favorites, but I can't quite explain why. Perhaps if I were a better writer. And if wishes were wings, we'd all fly.

Here's the thing about the Red Sox. I've been hearing some (still wishful) talk about a Sox/Cubs World Series. Everyone asks, "Who do you root for? The lovable loser Cubs, who always suck but seem so good-natured about it? Or the angry, bitter Red Sox, whose fans will burn down a good portion of the northeast corridor when/if they lose (or as all Sox fans put it, 'choke')?" Allow me to inject my own thoughts, as this is my own blog. I like the Sox. This is chiefly based on one primary emotion: fear. Fear of Red Sox fans. Instead of asking, "who deserves to win it all?" we should be asking "who can take a loss better?" And I don't think I have to convince too many people that the Cubs fans are in a far better position to get shot down than the Boston fans. The Red Sox are, and have been for quite a few years now, quite good. They just keep missing out on the big time - because of a curse, poor coaching, morale, who knows - and coming up short. The Chicago Cubs, however, suck. Not this year, no - they made it to the playoffs fair and square. But overall... not so much. While it may not be what the Baseball Gods had in mind, in this particular case the Red Sox seem the more prudent choice for a blessing. And, the Red Sox fans are bitter. I know because I lived with urlLink one of them for a couple years. Putting aside merit, history, luck, and fate, I would like to see them go all the way for a single reason: I like to imagine my friend Adam isn't having an aneurysm.

The thing about urlLink this entire situation (link goes to latest Post story) is that journalists seem to have forgotten their purpose. Yes, it's important to protect your source - when the source has a story. But if the story IS the source, things are different. In this case, leaking the name of a covert CIA operative is a far more important story than the actual name of the operative. In fact, that story is better left untold - but the idea that someone would leak such information? That's huge, and should have been (and should still be) reported by the journalists that have that information. Just my two cents. Journalists need to remember who they serve - the public, not their sources. And if burning a source is necessary to inform the public of a huge scandal, then burn your source and suffer the journalistic consequences. Lawyers have an obligation (sort of) to do the same thing, but I'll go into that later. When I have my DSL back. Goddamn SBC. Bring it back!

When I was but a wee lad, my parents divorced. It was all for the best, and that's not even hindsight talking. I thought it was for the best when it happened, and after a few sessions of obligatory post-split therapy, they were convinced that I really was okay with everything. Looking back, I wouldn't change a thing, mainly because I'm grateful on an almost daily basis for being raised the way I was. In those days, my family called itself middle class but I'm fairly certain we were, if anything, low-low-low middle class. But despite what I'm sure were some difficult financial situations, I never really noticed. My mom always managed to give us a good Christmas, and while I didn't have nearly as many of the newest toys as my friend Paul (whose parents were engaged in a bidding war for his love), I don't remember feeling poor at all. Part of that, as I look back now, was because my parents are so levelheaded when it comes to activities. We went to the museums a few times (far more than most kids growing up outside DC), but we also went to parks, and took long walks, and flew kites. Our vacations weren't to tropical isles but rather to visit family in the swamps of Brooksville, FL or the lakeside of Port Huron, MI. Okay, a lakeside vacation is pretty good, but that was just luck - if my grandparents lived in Ypsilanti, we would have visited them there. I guess my point is, thanks mom & dad. I may have been a colossal pain as a kid, but looking back I'm supremely grateful to have avoided being spoiled beyond recovery. I hope that, whether I have money or not, my kids can grow up the same way I did.

The latest entry over at urlLink It's My Life got me to thinking about what it really means if a person is deficient in character. I've never had a huge urge to send out things like Christmas cards, and I don't even think of "welcoming" new people to town (mostly because I think "who the hell am I to welcome you?"), and the only birthday cards I send are to those I think would appreciate it (and when I remember). But on the other hand, I try to be someone that will do anything for my friends and family. Lots of people may go through life firing of Hallmarks every week or two, but when the chips are down will they be there? Even if the chips aren't down, will they help you move, or drive you to the car repair shop, or pick you up from the airport? These are things that, if possible, I would do for almost any friend I have. I'm fairly certain that doesn't go both ways, but I don't really care about that because it's not part of my mental equation. It's not about getting something in return, it's about being reliable and someone people can count on. Fortunately (or as I sometimes see it, unfortunately) my friends don't take advantage of this personality trait very often. I'm not sure how many friends actually know the extent to which I'd go out of my way to help, and those that do know, don't ask me to. Since I'm not very good at expressing myself in other ways (cards, flowers, intricately-woven homemade quilts, etc.), I think it sometimes makes me come off as uncaring or aloof, and that's a shame. In case I forget, Happy Thanksgiving to those who celebrate it. Go Lions!

Now that California is my adopted state (for the near future, anyways), I feel I am obligated to make a post about our (as of today) urlLink new Governor. * Arnold's first act was to recall the massive car tax increase, and while I commend him for sticking to his promises, the actual promise itself is completely asinine. For me, California's fiscal problem was put into light when I attended the Medical Board of California board meeting two weeks ago. Because of the massive fiscal crisis, there is a hiring freeze on all government positions (except those that are absolutely necessary) and there have even been layoffs. Government layoffs! The Medical Board escaped layoffs because they have a special fund, but they haven't escaped the hiring freeze or the position cuts (a few months ago, all vacant positions in the government were "deleted", i.e. they will never be filled because they no longer exist). The Medical Board's "raison d'etre" is to protect the consumer. They do so by licensing doctors and by policing them. Now that their staff has been significantly cut, they are unable to follow up on any complaints save for the most grievous (like "My doctor shot me."). This means fraud, incompetence, and other such problems are going uninvestigated. What does this have to do with Arnold? His first act was to further California's mounting debt by eliminating a perfectly useful tax increase. Tough times call for tough measures, and as is usual with Republicans, Arnold has stepped up and pandered to the most basic (and fiscally irresponsible) group - the "No Car Tax" crowd. I saw them sweep another Republican into the governor's mansion in Virginia a few years ago, and am saddened that "enlightened" Californians have done the same thing. Yeah this is a bit of a rant (Arnold -> Medical Board -> Car Tax?) but it just pisses me off to witness the short-sightedness of voters. Please, cut my car tax! I don't need police, or fire protection, or any other essential government services if I can pay $100 less every year! *I hate the San Diego Union-Tribune, so I tend to link to better (better meaning "readable") papers if possible.

Can't live with 'em, can't bury 'em in the backyard. It seems like many of the women in my life are experiencing some interesting phenomenon in their respective love lives. I'm not sure if it's the season for strife and fluctuation, or just a coincidence, but I'm leaning towards mere chancery simply because each person is having highly different experiences. The only common bond is that there is a guy involved in all of them (my lesbian friends are pretty content right now). Needless to say I won't be getting into any specifics, but from my own perspective I find it odd that there are so many different kinds of guys out there, and they all seem to be matched with women who are a) smarter than they are and b) better equipped to deal with relationships. There are guys who are moving too fast, guys who are weaseling their way back in, guys who were never in to begin with and are delusional, and of course guys who are moving too slow. It may be that my perspective (as friend and brother) is skewed, but it seems like most of these guys are barely able to figure out how to work these relationships correctly. Some are better at it than others, but in some ways it almost seems like they're matched up incorrectly. If I could just play God and rearrange the relationships so that neuroses matched, would that be better or worse? Is the guy who refuses to commit better suited with a girl who is the same way, or is that part of his appeal that would be lost on someone of the same mind? Similarly, is the guy who wants to settle down better suited to a girl looking for marriage, or is the mix of opposites what provides that oh-so-crucial spark? They say one woman's stalker is another's prince charming, and right now that seems to be very true. But I think that analyzing these behaviors is a little bit like seeing shapes in the clouds; it's fun, but ultimately useless to do so. The bonds between women and men, in all relationships from the serious to the casual, go much deeper than can be studied with a macrosociological-type approach. But that forces us to deal with each relationship as it exists, and while not having any sort of manual or guidelines may be frustrating, it's probably the best way to live. I'm pretty lucky to have so many female friends, I think, because it gives me the opportunity to reflect on my own behavior, past and present (though present is mercifully drama-free right now). Whether this "insider information" will ever prove beneficial while in the throes of a difficult relationship remains to be seen, but for now I'm pretty content to just listen, reflect, and offer to beat the bejesus out of anyone who hurts the people I care about.

Heroes? Really? I've long wondered exactly how much credit to give to those who serve in life-saving professions. It's a given that they save lives, and for that I'm sure we're all very grateful. However, are they all "heroes" just for doing what they're paid to do? If that's the case, then perhaps those that help people indirectly are all heroes, and those that help their family by working crap jobs are heroes, and so forth. urlLink This article on Salon.com has an interesting take on the now routine practice of calling any firefighter that fights a fire a Hero. The same sentiment can be extended to those in the military, and perhaps to police persons and EMT's. Unless we reinstate the draft, everyone in the military is there because they chose to be there. So when they head overseas, and are (sadly) killed by hostile forces, I'm not going to jump to calling them heroes. Not that military folk can't be heroes; I would simply rather see that term reserved for truly heroic actions. Saving your entire platoon from enemy attack might make you a hero, just as rushing into a burning building to save a family might as well. But showing up for work? Not that heroic, in my book. Perhaps "noble" is a better word for some who engage in these professions. This entire line of thought coincides nicely with my thoughts on those who are killed while serving in the military - that while it is sad when someone dies, it is certainly not sadder when they are killed in combat, and in fact maybe it's less sad. After all, you know what you're getting into when you join up to Serve Your Country; if a war breaks out, then your job is to go and, if necessary, die. It's not tragic, it's what they signed up to do. Maybe this seems like a cynical viewpoint, but I would stress again that it doesn't mean I have any less respect for those who work in such risky areas. But we should reserve our greatest titles and deepest sorrows for occasions that truly deserve it.

Also, on Thursday I twisted my ankle on Hilary's stairs so I used that as an excuse for a few days. It's better now. This whole Saddam thing is still bothering me. Headlines like "Dean's Toast Now" are just stupid. First of all, the American people are very much what-have-you-done-for-me-latelies. While I'm sure we'll all remember that Saddam is in custody next November, the euphoria felt by slack-jawed yokels because of his capture will have faded by late January. Second of all, Dean has a perfectly defensible (and smart) position: he didn't want to go to war in the first place! At least not without the UN's backing. He never said it was because the military wouldn't catch Saddam, or that Saddam belongs in power. Anyone who thinks that the anti-war types have been dealt a huge blow by this development is a complete moron. This is just a step, a step in an unjust military action that was started incorrectly (and possibly illegally) but must be seen to completion to avoid screwing the Iraqis like we did last time.

So they found Senor Hussein, that's nice. Seems largely irrelevant to the United States' interests in combatting terrorism, but it's nice. He was, after all, a fairly evil man that should have been run out of town a long time ago. Me, I would have preferred he was run out by his own people (as all bad dictators should be), or at least the UN, but I suppose once we made the mistake of charging into Iraq, the least we could do was topple his regime. I guess it puts a little karma back in the U.S.'s possession; our previous international machinations (Iran Contra, Gulf War I, our outstanding work in Cambodia and Chile...) have certainly been bad moves, especially in hindsight. I don't see this changing anything in the near future, though. Sure, Bush is likely to get a political bump out of this, but most people know that Saddam wasn't behind 9/11 and that Osama is still out there. Frankly, I'm not sure why catching Osama should lead to an increase in political clout, since any President who had to deal with the horrors of 9/11 would be hunting him like a dog. If he's caught while Bush is in charge, it's not really because Bush single-handedly tackled him to the ground. Similarly, if he's caught in 4 years and someone else is President, it won't necessarily be because of anything THEY did either. On the other hand, perhaps a future President would change strategy - unfortunately for Bush, it's his prize to lose. Future leaders can say they increased pressure/men/resources to find Bin Laden (and thus did a better job than Bush), whereas if Bush finds him it will be (in my mind) the natural outcome of 9/11. He can't really say he's looking harder, because if he is then why did he just start now? I've often wondered (and this will be a rant but hey, it's my blog so why not) what the best approach to international diplomacy is. The United States is quite powerful, so are we being negligent if we refuse to step in when other countries/leaders do bad things? Or are we being arrogant when we do step in? I'm of both minds, because sometimes it seems the practical thing to do is stop mass genocide when it occurs. Places like Rwanda, Somalia, and the Congo all witnessed hundreds of thousands of deaths (millions?) but we did little more than attempt to send aid and work with the UN. We stepped in to fight Saddam, but he was brutal on a smaller scale. Why haven't we sent massive forces to Africa? I'm not so cynical as to think it's entirely about oil, because that's far too simplistic an answer to a conundrum that has spanned multiple presidencies and worldviews. Maybe stopping mass murder is what the UN is for, but unfortunately the UN is toothless without America's support. And if we give our support to one operation over another, isn't that just a way of masking our own actions under a cloak of UN authority? Perhaps this is why foreign affairs is such a contentious issue - there are so many nuances that it makes finding an "exact" solution difficult at best. Still, there's something to be said for sovereignty. We wouldn't want Iraq coming in here and deposing our President, no matter how much some of us might despise him. We may be in a better position to control our destiny than the people of Iraq, but isn't that still fundamentally their choice? Isn't the United States a better world leader if we set examples of how democracy can work, rather than bomb the hell out of those who have yet to work it out? That is all for now. Oh yeah, 3 finals down, 1 to go. Then I'm outta here!

The problem with political ideologies is that they tend to skew heavily in one direction or another. Something is "completely wrong" or "absolutely right", and anyone who disagrees is evil. This trend used to be more obvious among conservatives, who are big fans of Good vs. Evil, but I see it more and more on the left these days, as well. I have yet to decide whether that's terribly wrong (I'm leaning towards "It is.") but I believe the cause behind this polarization is the current militarized state of the world. The last time we had a huge global conflict, it was fairly clear to most people even during the conflict that there was a good and an evil. Nazi Germany was taking over most of Europe, there were reports of death camps, and the Allies were trying to stop them. Looking back over 50 years, it seems easy to make the distinction, so perhaps I'm assuming more clarity than actually existed. But nowadays, we have no such clarity beyond "killing people is wrong". But the terrorists in or from the middle east - they have some fairly significant grievances against the United States and her allies. Of course I'm not saying it excuses anything, but the entire situation (Israel and Palestine, for example) is very murky and difficult to slog through. You can't just label someone "the bad guy" and have it stick. There is no Hitler, no Mussolini, no Axis. The end result is that people want to feel emotionally charged in "the war on terror". But you can't become emotionally charged when you're not sure exactly who your friends and enemies are, or what your goal is, so you make those things up. And then, in the spirit of artificial line-drawing, you demonize those who oppose you. Anti-war protestors thus become cowards and traitors, and war supporters become war-mongers and terrorists. My point? The black and white days of WW2 are over. It's nice to reminisce about an "easier time" when the bad guys wore swastikas and did monstrous things, but we must leave that in the past. Trying to shoehorn the current state of the world into a model created 50 years ago is like trying to squeeze a square peg into a round hole. Oh, and for the record I'm against the war but now that we're in Iraq, I think we need to stay a long, long time. I don't have any idea about what should be done in Israel, nor do I know whether globalization is a Good Thing or a Bad Thing. I believe in room for argument and for disagreement, but maybe tolerance is exactly what some people would like to see less of.

Yet another example of why copyright law is urlLink far to protective . First of all, the NFL chooses to use broadcast television (not cable) and broadcast signals are the public domain . Granted this doesn't change the fact that their broadcast is intellectual property (although that's a stretch, too - it's only because there's a grain of creativity in an NFL televised game). It should be the case that anything broadcast over the air is loses its public performance right, period (one of the rights guaranteed by copyright is the right to publicly perform -- and to restrict others from performing -- your works). It's not like pay-per-view boxing, or pay-per-view concerts. The people who want to go to Superbowl parties can see the game anywhere. Clearly, the admission fees for those parties are for the atmosphere, the food, and the other accomodations, not the game itself. So Fuck You, NFL. And goddamnit, why can't we get some sensible copyright legislation in this country so that these insane corporate monsters (I'm looking at you too, RIAA) will stop harassing every single consumer in existence! Back to writing my law review comment ("Sensible Copyright Legislation In the Age of the CTEA").

So much of life is timing. If not for timing, many of our most significant events might not have occurred, or would have occurred differently. Many jobs are won or lost through the mere timing of it all, which can be frustrating to people. On the upside, when timing prevents something from happening, you don't know that for sure - but when timing is on your side, it can be easy to see and give it all the credit. My point? I'm not sure I have one, except to say it's been coming up in a variety of ways the last few weeks, and it's just something to think about. Most people, I think, talk about timing in those two big areas - employment and relationships. As noted above, it can be hard to see when you miss out on a job because of bad timing. But often times, relationships are just the opposite. Whether you characterize it as "bad" or "good" timing is sort of subjective (because "bad timing" could have put you in or out of a relationship, but you'd only say that if you weren't happy about it or the eventual outcome), but you can spend a lot of time pondering the subject. More than most probably should. Because timing, you see, is irrelevent. We only get one pass at life - at any given situation, any given year - so discussion of missed opportunities or "bad timing" is almost useless beyond simple nostalgia. It's not "timing" - it's what happened . This is also why I don't believe in fate, by the way. Timing and fate imply that things could have gone another way, and while obviously it could have gone another way, it didn't. Nothing goes two ways because life is linear, and the next opportunity, no matter how similar is never the same. This is not meant to be depressing, because even though fate and timing are bogus, if there's a connection, or a reason for two people to know each other, then even if you miss out on the first opportunity (or feel like you did), a true bond or connection will give you alternate "bites at the apple." It may not result in the same type of relationship (friends instead of more-than-friends, for instance), but the phrase "meant to be" can mean many, many things. The end result, in my opinion, is that you really must seize every opportunity to the utmost of your ability, because there are no second chances. There are other chances, but if you miss the first boat, the second one will always be different. The "seize opportunity" idea doesn't always have to mean action, however. An interesting thing about hindsight is that it's not always "I should have acted!" but rather in some instances "thank God I didn't do X." And that's exactly why timing and fate are crap: for every "missed opportunity" or instance of "bad timing," something good will happen that, with the introduction of hindsight into the mix, means all "bad timing" was oops, good timing! Because if what you had wanted to work out had actually worked out, this "good event" wouldn't have occurred. But nobody can see those things coming, so in the end all you can do is live, and stop worrying about what should or shouldn't have happened. ps. Sacramento is a pretty nasty city. Boring and cold!

I've noticed that I get a lot (well, a handful every day) of hits from people searching for "reversed and remanded". Thus it occurs to me that perhaps I should explain what that means, if it isn't obvious. It's a term that appellate courts use when they make a decision, reversing the previous court and remanding (sending it back) to that court for rehearing according to the new rules. Because sometimes when the Supreme Court (or any appellate court) rules, it doesn't just put the case to rest - more must be done, under the constraints now imposed by the new decision. So the lower courts receive the "reversed and remanded" cases and deal with them as necessary. Of course there's also results like "affirmed" or "remanded for further fact-finding" but those aren't the titles of this blog, so I'm not explaining those. Suckers!

Warning: legal post ahead. Caution to all who are prone to drowsiness; Invitation to all who are prone to insomnia. urlLink Brown v. Board of Education Today in Con(stitutional) Law, we discussed Brown, which as most everybody (inside and outside of law school) knows is the landmark case that desegregated schools and, as a domino effect, the rest of the country as well. Eventually. We learned about Brown in highschool, if I recall, and again in college (if you had any sort of U.S. History or sociological class), but my Con Law professor pointed out quite astutely (he's very smart) that perhaps Brown is not the best opinion ever. For reasons known only to lawyers, Brown is widely seen as a key, but Constitutionally unfaithful, decision in the civil rights movement. There is no constitutional basis for declaring "separate but equal" illegal, at least on the surface. You must dig deep into the theoretical interpretation realm, using "originalism" and "Framer principles", to find any basis for the decision. Of course, everyone thinks (and they're right) that Brown is correct in outcome - it's just ironic that such a bastion of historical jurisprudence is so weakly constructed. While we're on the topic, it was noted in class that the social theory many people associate with desegregation - that segregation is wrong because it creates ideas of inferiority among those who are segregated out - is a rather morally bankrupt idea itself. It is often cited as the major reason that segregation is wrong (at least, the major concrete reason - everyone knows it's wrong on a higher, more ethically-grounded but logically barren level of thought) but such a proposition suggests that those who are segregated out are also more emotionally and mentally fragile than those who do the segregating. This is a position that is both insulting and demeaning to African-Americans, and while ideas of inferiority may have been created in individual circumstances, to imply that an entire group would consider themselves lesser is just as racist an idea as "separate but equal". Assuming, as many did before Brown, that we can create "separate but equal" schools that truly are equal, what then is the driving force behind desegregation if we recognize that the inferiority reason is untenable? I would offer that rather than using desegregation as a way to help African-Americans, it is a way to "deracist" white America. That rather than balancing our moral obligation to desegregation on the idea that African-Americans would feel inferior, desegregation should instead be viewed as removing a not-so-subtle framework of white superiority from society, thus undermining the racist reinforcement that institutionalized superiority has on those who see and live in it. This is not, as it might first seem, a way to cast all whites as white-supremacists, but rather a recognition that ideas such as white superiority are harder to fight when they are reinforced by racist public policies like "separate but equal". Removing the system (as we did) thus allows for a more level playing field as we fight to educate and enlighten some of our more ignorant citizenry.
