It may be January 7th, but that's never too late for a year-end wrap-up, right? BOOKS Everybody knows all I have time to read these days are textbooks, but I did manage to work through a few non-school texts, and there are a couple that stood out. In a Sunburned Country - Never have I read a travel book so entertaining and so effective at driving me to go somewhere. Bill Bryson discusses Australia from a ground's eye perspective, without lists and pricing guides, and the end result is a desire to travel to a country that, until a few months ago, I hadn't thought much about. Copyrights and Copywrongs - Despite what it looks like, this was not a book I read for class. It is, however, a really interesting look at the history and people behind the formation of Copyright law in this country. Unfortunately, those may be the only two (good) books I've finished this year - as noted earlier, I'm trying to work my way through a couple more, but I don't give a thumb's up or down until I've devoured the entire thing, cover-to-cover. MOVIES I saw many movies this year (like most years) thanks to the glorious service that is urlLink Netflix . I won't go into why each one was good (I don't have the time) but if you haven't, check out: Big Fish (though technically I saw it last Saturday, it's a "2003" movie) Kill Bill Vol. 1 Lord of the Rings: Return of the King Lost in Translation (probably my favorite film this year) Master & Commander: The Far Side of the World Pirates of the Caribbean X2: X-Men United (yes it's a comic book movie, but I'll be damned if it wasn't quite entertaining) More later when I can remember what came out in the earlier part of the year. I have such a bad memory for things like this... You'll notice that some of my choices are popcorn flics; unlike some who consider themselves fans of movies, I can appreciate "fun" movies as much as thinkers. And while I might like thinkers better overall, a movie's entertainment value is not necessarily inversely proportional to its quality. Onwards! GAMES A series of poor financial decisions this year (i.e. deciding to stay in law school) have left me with the means to play fewer games than I would have liked. Still, some stood out as excellent: Grand Theft Auto: Vice City - graphic violence warnings aside, GTA:VC did nothing but improve upon it's predecessor (GTA3) in every area except graphics (which were already quite good). Age of Mythology - it can be difficult to do real-time strategy well; for every good (Starcraft, the Age series) there are many bad (the newer Command & Conquers, any Star Wars-based RTS, and others). This is one of the good, and thanks to Jason I'm now playing the Titans Expansion, which reminds me just how good the original was. Knights of the Old Republic - I just got this for Christmas, but so far I've played almost 20 hours and am getting the impression that I have many, many hours to go. That's so refreshing in these days of 6-hour games (Medal of Honor series, I'm looking in your direction...) SimCity 4 - as always, a marked improvement over the previous incarnation (which itself was excellent). Now that I think about it, I was supposed to send this to Adam. You still want it Adam? Text Twist - the only thing that got me through Intro to IP this year. THE BAD Disappointments? Sure, we've all got some. The Matrix movies were a let-down, in my opinion, because they added nothing new to the series and by the time they came out this year, the special effects were old hat. As briefly noted above, the Medal of Honor expansion packs (Spearhead and, so far, Breakthrough) have been too short and way to hard on my system. Much more engrossing and graphicly-rich games run far better, and it just pisses me off to see such poor quality in such a great series. Fortunately, I think I've dodge most of the other bombs of 2003. Or perhaps I've simply blocked them from my mind. On a completely separate note: urlLink Gibbs ? Really? I was thinking of posting some commentary on gay marriage/civil unions, but I'm not sure what to say. It just seems like such an obvious good idea (allowing civil unions, not prohibiting them) that I honestly fail to see the controversy. I've asked around for some sort of rational explanation, but my pool of mostly liberal friends isn't the best place to seek differing views. So now I ask you, oh anonymous Reading Community. Why is it such a bad idea? Does anybody really think it will weaken the institute of marriage any further than, say, all those reality shows, Las Vegas, or Carmen Electra? If there's an explanation out there that doesn't devolve into simple anti-gay hysteria, I've yet to hear it. So step up, Faithful Readers, and tell me what you think or what you've heard. For an example of rational thought, I'd point out that while many highly religious people object to abortion, an argument about protecting potential life (whether or not you're a Christian) can at least be made to support the pro-life side. I may not agree, but I acknowledge the existence. Anti-gun control arguments often center on history, tradition or protection, and though it may be a mask for criminal paranoia it's an effective mask because there are some good arguments. But anti-gay marriage? Name me an argument that isn't directly supported by a bias against homosexuals, and I'll consider it a legitimate issue. Until then, I find this entire debate of questionable value because it is far too lopsided in favor of allowing civil unions.

I blogged too soon, apparently. I was scrambling for a topic and resorted to using the Friday Five, but mere minutes later I read that the word on the political street is that Nader's going to run again. That's just screaming for comment (because it pisses me off) so two posts in 20 minutes! 1) Nader has less chance of winning than I do. Most Nader supporters (and I'm not sure how many there will be this time around) argue that he forces people to see the Democratic Party for what it is - just another corporately-owned machine of oppression. Or something. While it may be true that the Democrat Party is not (and has not been for some time) the party of the true progressive movement, it's completely asinine to pretend they are no different, idealogical or otherwise, from the Republican Party. It's also naive to a profound degree, and by supporting a completely useless candidate, Nader fans are putting millions of children, single mothers, poor families, and foreign countries at risk of another Bush presidency. 2) What did this accomplish last time? Nader's candidacy handed the presidency to an evangelical nutball with the IQ of a bathmat and a staff of hugely conservative idealogues. Is the country better off than it was in 2000? Are we more progressive? Are there more jobs? Are we a respected member of the world community? I think we all know the answers to those questions. Kerry may have plenty of bad faults, but he's nowhere NEAR as bad as Bush, and anyone acting to undermine his candidacy is a traitor to the progressive cause, period. 3) "This wouldn't have happened if Dean/Kucinich were the candidate." Perhaps that's true. But if either of them become the nominee (unlikely now that Dean's officially out) then the Democrats would lose. What many fiercely progressive individuals forget is that politics is not about extremes. Dean is an extreme within the Democratic Party, and in the end he would have been routed by Bush. Kerry is much more centered, and even if his politics don't match up with most liberals, he's much more open to those ideals than Bush and Co. He also appeals to the Democrat-in-theory swath of America that votes Democratic but thinks like a conservative. I would love for this country to be able to elect a far left President. Truly, I would. But elections are about majorities, or at least pluralities, and the majority of this country does not want such a person in the White House. I may disagree, and I may work to persuade that vast majority, but you cannot discount their voting power. That power must be wined and dined, and someone like Dean (and definitely Nader) cannot do that. Kerry can, he can actually win this election, and any liberal who stands in his way should be stripped of their tree-hugging badge and sent to Canada. Politics is a game of inches, of gradual change, and once liberals accept that fact, real change can begin. /end sermon Perhaps tomorrow I will tear into the anti-gay marriage crowd. But see how pervasive that movement seems to be? That's why we can't elect Nader, or Dean, in this country. Not yet.

I've noticed an increasing frustration with California's drivers lately, and I've been struggling to determine where my road rage comes from. I've always been annoyed by bad drivers - everybody who's been in a car with me more than a couple times knows that. But it seems enhanced out here, and after careful (i.e. not at all thought-out) consideration, I have a theory. California is home to Drivers. Everybody drives here, partly because the mass transit in most California cities is piss-poor (the exception being of course San Francisco) and partly because things are much more spread out. Out here, the distance to a friend's house might be the same distance as it is from Arlington, VA to Bethesda, MD (perhaps through DC). The massive highway system in California helps move that along nicely, so aside from the environmental issues (of which there are many) it seems to work speedily. The flipside, however, is that anytime a California driver goes somewhere new, they drive. New restaurant tonight? New club? New park or theater or marina? Let's hop in the car with a Mapquest printout and find it! This is not a bad thing (or even unavoidable), but my theory is that it leads to many, many people driving around looking for things and thus making complete asses out of themselves (because they're going really slow, or cutting across 2 lanes to make an exit or a turn, etc.). Contrast this with my theoretical vision of the east coast (or at least the DC area) where people often drive only to work and back, or don't drive at all. When I lived in Arlington, I used my car sparingly and most often only to go west (away from the city). Any adventures into the city were undertaken using the vastly superior Metro system. Even those who don't live very close often drive to the Metro station nearest their house, and then metro in to avoid the hassle of driving. My final analysis, then? People in DC are jerks behind the wheel, but as a percentage of drivers more of them know where they're going at any given time than those who are tooling around Southern California. This is not to say that Californians are worse drivers; just that when given the opportunity to be lost or confused, most Californians do so while behind the wheel, whereas many (I wouldn't dare guesstimate a percentage) Washingtonians do so while staring at a Metro map or a grid of downtown DC. You may begin punching numerous holes in my theory.

I don't watch as much TV as I used to. Part of that is because there's so little good television on these days - a common lament, I know - but what's worse is that it seems as though anything remotely daring or well-written gets axed and "My Big Fat Obnoxious Fiance" gets greenlighted for another 25 seasons. Now, I'm all for escapist television, that's what television is for, and I wouldn't normally express my disdain for anything that others enjoy. To each his/her own, that's what I think. But I can't help but conclude that the huge rise in reality TV, and the subsequent drop in entertaining fictional television, is correlated. In the last few years, several entertaining shows have come and gone, including Freaks and Geeks, Andy Richter Controls the Universe, Buffy, Futurama, Boomtown, and now (as you may have heard) Angel. If you were a fan of Buffy and you don't watch Angel, you should be ashamed. Ashamed! It has turned into an easily equivalent and often times superior work, and those who complain about it being too complicated are just being silly. After all, if you can keep up with Buffy's convoluted and confusing mythology, Angel's is (was) a cakewalk. The damage is done, and I'm not so naive to think that any amount of new viewership could save the show (nor that I have any means of increasing said viewership), but I feel frustrated. Not for the cast or crew or anything silly like that, but rather because once Angel goes, I will no longer have Must See TV. I can remember back a few years ago when Buffy was crackling with energy, West Wing was on fire, ER was riveting, and even a number of sitcoms (Raymond, Scrubs, even Friends) were quite funny. Now? West Wing has lost its edge, ER seems soulless, and Raymond and Friends seem to be letting the clock run out so they can retire. Scrubs is still entertaining, but NBC moves it so often (it's on Tuesdays now, right?) that I expect it will also be cancelled or "put on hiatus". And what replaces these shows? Average Joe: Hawaii. Or something about midgets dating. Or the Surreal Life (I'm looking at you, WB). I don't have a problem with such shows, even if I'm not a fan, until they replace the ones that are daring and creative. The networks often whine (though I suspect they know) that they're losing market to cable, but everyone knows why that is. The Sopranos, Sex and the City, even Dead Like Me (on Showtime) and The L-Word (which is basically just hot lesbians, but still more substantial than 90% of other TV) are far more riveting and more creative. I don't suppose I have a point here, I'm just sad. Sad to know that Angel won't be back, sad at the prospects of another few years of reality TV upstaging quality work. Sad that although I enjoy Law & Order and CSI, neither show is particularly groundbreaking or innovative. Sad that the Simpsons is the only thing left, and that's a half-hour long.

Today is President's Day, though you wouldn't know it to see everyone on campus. USD does not believe in honoring our nation's forefathers, perhaps because they are a bunch of communists, or fascists, or Catholics. Wait, that last one sounds right. My favorite ex-President (clearly he'd have to be ex, since I'm fairly certain that the current occupant is a shaved chimpanzee with a good tailor) is Franklin Roosevelt. Not only did he pull the country out of a massive depression, but he also put the country in the one war this century in which it was probably a good idea to participate. My choice is not surprising to anyone who knows me as a fairly dyed-in-the-wool liberal, but it is worth stating nonetheless. Also not a terribly bold choice, but given this country's history of electing on white, upper-class men to the office, I don't find myself staring at a rainbow of opportunity. Up until the 20th century (and even until today, though I believe the effect is lessened because of the media's watchdog role) the presidency was a place of corruption, and the commander-in-chief spent more time provoking class warfare than he did advancing the nation. That, or he was a doddering moron - I'm looking at you, Warren G. Harding. My memory of Presidents past is fading, as I haven't had a good American History course since 1999 (and my attempt to plow through A People's History of the United States is almost stagnant at this point), but Roosevelt is probably the cream of the crop. Despite whatever errors in judgment he may have made (Pearl Harbor, Japanese internment camps, spending programs that eclipsed even my rather ultraliberal view of the scope of government power). Don't even get me started on Reagan.

Valentine's Day is on the horizon again, so I'll go ahead and post a quick commentary on the day like pretty much every other blogging fool in the universe. Valentine's Day is sweet and cute and appropriate for those who like that sort of thing. It's good for those who do not express their feelings often, because it forces them (mostly men, but some women too) to say how they feel rather than let their actions speak for them. I think both expressing yourself verbally and through your actions is appropriate, but I've never quite understood why it should be okay for February 14th to be the only day that occurs. If you love someone, really love them, you should be making that known in little ways every day, and occasionally in a big way, but not because the calendar says so. Yeah, that's a bit of a cynical argument, but it's not because I'm bitter (I hope). It just seems like if I do something overly special on Valentine's Day, it lumps me in with all the shmucks who never do anything special unless it's mandated by a holiday. I want to give roses because roses should be given, to buy jewelry because she deserves jewelry, to go away for the weekend because I enjoy her company. But not because it's the 14th and I have to. In the interests of full disclosure, I'm not doing anything on Valentine's Day and I'm okay with that. I mean, clearly I'm okay with that (see above) but I don't think there's anyone in my life right now who's not okay with that, so it works out nicely. If it's as nice as it was today, I may have to go outside!

Upfront disclosure: this stems from a conversation, nothing more. I feel like I need disclosures these days or everyone assumes some exciting/bad/strange thing happened to spark posts like this. Nope! Just good ol' fashioned conversation. A friend of mine was recently lamenting the fact that when interviewing for non-profit (or low profit) legal positions, the interview process is often quite unprofessional and sometimes downright crappy. Having worked in the non-profit world, I noted that actually this is quite common, and that (in my opinion) it stems from a conflict between idealists and those who want to "get the job done." Idealism is where most non-profits start. Someone with a vision for changing the world. Visionaries are key to society, because it takes vision and idealism to bring social problems to the attention of the generally ignorant public. Difficulties arise, however, when the idealist realizes that orating from a box on the street corner of a major city may be personally fulfilling, but if you want to affect real change, you have to organize and create a system and a structure for doing so. The idealist must learn to compromise, and compromise is a difficult thing to master, especially when you believe so very strongly that your goals are just. When I say compromise, I don't necessarily mean compromising in terms of morals or goals (though that may be necessary), but rather in putting together a team, an organization, a gameplan for changing the world. In doing so, you need professional people who can work the system, but professional people are often not idealists. It works against you to be idealistic, especially when engaging in politics, but the idealists who run the non-profit don't want to compromise and hire those who aren't 100% in-line with their goals. Instead, you get very smart, very idealistic and charming people who can't actually hold a meeting or write a letter to save their lives. They have no professional experience, nor do they want any, and in the end (because the top tiers of any non-profit are often filled with more idealists than professionals) they drive off employees who would like to help but feel ineffectual ("beating my fists against a brick wall" is a common complaint) in such an environment. So, we end up at my friend's situation, which is just a window into that world. Those who go to hire law students are often higher-level employees, and because of that they are often ideal-driven and not practical. They don't know how to properly interview, or how to consider alternative viewpoints (even if those viewpoints differ on only minor points), and they end up losing out on very capable, intelligent people because those people don't want to work in such a stifling and startlingly inefficient environment. There are exceptions to this, of course. My time in the non-profit world was quite good, and while some of the problems I've mentioned were common, the organization benefitted greatly from having a leader who was both idealistic and capable. But I've worked with many other organizations who could not have found their way into a congressional meeting with a map of the capital and an engraved invitation, simply because they had alienated the few people who knew how to make such meetings happen.

My Legislation class is currently discussing campaign finance reform and the justifications behind it. It is quite a heated debate (in law school class terms, that means more than one person speaks) and I had an idea to share but class ended before I could. Enter the blog! Instead of having complicated statutory law and administrative agencies governing elections (i.e. the Bipartisan Campaign Reform Act, FECA, the FEC), why don't we just prohibit all campaign contributions? Bear with me for a second: there is an argument that donating money to your candidate of choice is akin to speaking, because you are "saying" that you support that candidate and his or her ideals. But if we decide that's crap (and I'm inclined to say it is - money is property; speech is speech), then we can restrict ALL campaign shenanigans. No more PACs and wealthy donors, no more corporate influence (at least around elections). One person, one vote, and that's how it's run. Sure, you lose a substantial ability to reach the public. TV commercials are expensive, but (again my view) it seems to me that campaign commercials run because other campaign commercials are running and saying the opposite thing. If there were NO campaign commercials, NO fundraisers, but instead most public discourse occurred via news shows, debates, and newspaper articles - would we be worse off? Wouldn't that be simpler? We could require television stations to carry politically important programming -- something not remotely unusual, as such a system was in place for a long time until fairly recently scrapped -- and potential politicians would have to stick primarily to issues. The downside (if you see it as one) is that the news media would be a much bigger player in campaigning, because it would be the primary source for candidate information (whether it be newspaper, radio, or TV). And as FOX News shows us, the media isn't exactly unbiased. But with so many sources of information (including the Internet, which would be instrumental) at our fingertips, I would almost argue that this system would leave a more-informed public, not a less-informed one. Instead of having to sort through attack ads, fluff pieces, and reams of 3rd party materials attacking or supporting one candidate or another, the entire process would be hugely simplified. Lobbying, then, would be restricted to fully post-election occurrences. Since PACs and interest groups wouldn't be allowed to donate to, or even support, candidates for office, they'd be restricted to lobbying only already-elected officials on behalf of their interests. This would give the Voters a much stronger hand in government, because when allied with the media (and not confused by special interests) they might be more informed and thus less willing to stand for corruption in office. Although influencing elected officials post-election would still be challenging, the Voters would have a clearer trump card to play: the ability to vote bad politicians out of office. Without 3rd parties crowding the electoral system, such a trump card becomes the powerful tool envisioned by the Founders. Or, perhaps I'm a communist. The freedom of speech issues in this theoretical scheme are clear - telling an organization they can't act to support a candidate is not only crossing the line, it's pretty much obliterating it, at least under current readings of the 1st Amendment. My only comment on that (since I'm no 1st Amend. expert) is that perhaps freedom of speech shouldn't be allowed to corrupt democracy itself, and if we allow speech to overrule election laws (even as draconian as my proposed laws) then scandal, corruption, and illegitimacy will pervade our society, and eventually we'll lose speech as well.

Yesterday's ConLaw class was interesting because we began exploring Freedom of Speech. More specifically, we discussed the reasoning behind "Free Speech" as a right - why? Why Free Speech and not some other "right" like Freedom to Be Employed or Freedom to Eat at Denny's? My favorite argument was, as is often the case, the most philosophical: freedom of speech is a basic freedom because truth, and seeking truth, is one of humanity's most basic goals. The best, and only, way to determine the strength and validity of our ideas is to let them into the "marketplace of ideas" and watch them battle for supremacy over "false" ideas. In a free and open marketplace, truth will always win. Marek pointed out that this approach is a wee bit unrealistic, as there is no such thing as a marketplace of free exchange, especially when you reach the broadest audience. While that is probably true, I still think Truth is the best goal to have. Everyone thinks their ideas are true, or at least more true than others, but the only way to make sure is to let those ideas out. As Justice Holmes pointed out, "the best test of truth is the power of the thought to get itself accepted in the competition of the market." And only those who fear truth will shy away from speaking their mind. I don't even believe that sometimes Truth is dangerous, at least on a large national or international scale. Sure, sometimes Truth is a bad idea (i.e. when it hurts someone for no reason) but that's not the same thing as The Truth about our foreign policy, or The Truth about our national security. The current administration doesn't seem to share this view, because in their eyes those who question their Truth are damaging society - this could not be farther from the reality of the situation. I'm going to stop now because the word "truth" is starting to sound funny to me. You know how words start sounding incorrect, the more you hear them (or, as it happens, type them)? I've am afflicted with that particular malady now, so it's on to Tax Law where truth plays no real part in our discussion.

Sometimes the mood can strike you just right, and like the jolted-aware feeling that comes when you slam on the brakes to avoid a previously unnoticed pedestrian, you step outside. Outside yourself, your apartment or home, your workplace or place of learning, your city, your country, and your world. It happens to everyone, some more often than others, and it's been said that certain mind-altering and illegal intoxicants can up the frequency of such occurrences. What you see when you step out is never very predictable, at least to you. Do you see your life as it might have been, had you chosen to go away to Seattle for school instead of staying close to your home? Or perhaps you realize, for the first time, that there are millions of people who have never heard of Starbucks living thousands of miles away from the spot where a few minutes ago you complained that your coffee did not have enough sugar? Maybe it's the simple realization that this is all there is. It's a realization that, at once, is both horrifyingly claustrophobic and calming. It's a feeling not unlike the one you get when watching a scene in a movie where the camera zooms out and moves in at the exact same moment. Everyone should have one of those last ones. It reminds us that, beyond the day-to-day tedium of papers that must be turned in and appointments that must be scheduled and kept, life is pure opportunity. Every soul, from the man living in a hut in a third-world country to the woman working in a skyscraper in downtown Chicago, has the innate ability to do anything. There may be minor exceptions, like terraforming on Mars or playing point guard for the Knicks, which are available only to a select few, but the vast majority of human experiences are available to every single person. You just have to realize it. Of course, that's not the hard part. After realization must come action, a seizing of one's own destiny, so to speak. But that's probably where 99% of the world steps back from the edge, climbs down from the roof and stops staring at the night sky. After all, you've got the cable bill to pay, a not-very-interesting social function to attend on Saturday, and a persistent headache that never seems to fade completely. Sure, at some point you'll write that novel, live in Tokyo for 6 months, spend a summer sailing to the Caribbean, and learn to play jazz guitar. Just not today.

I have friends of all types. Some, I can share 5 words with and my point is taken. It's mostly guys that communicate this way, and it suits our needs nicely. An entire conversation can be as follows: "Wow." "Yeah, I saw." "Damn." "You wish." "Shut up." "I used to date someone like that, but with less..." "Yeah." Note the end of the conversation is heralded by the inclusion of too much information. This is not a bad thing, but guys have to take care lest they inadvertently reveal far too much (i.e. "I used to date a girl named Kate..." bzzzzt! Thanks for playing but I'm afraid you've exceeded your limit for today!). In that I am simultaneously blessed and cursed with an abundance of female friends, I sometimes have the unique opportunity to have the same conversation in an entirely different format. This format includes many, many words, analogies, stories about previous experiences, and sometimes more than a few positive affirmations ("Well she's not as hot as YOU, of course..."). Each type of conversation has its strengths and its weaknesses. But the reason we have these conversations, that can sometimes differ. Some people don't like to talk about their private life, even with close friends. It's not a bad thing, it's just a personality trait. The key is to identify people who are like this so that you don't get miffed when they choose not to share. Others will share every detail of their sordid history with the guy selling coffee downstairs, because that's the way they are. I tend to straddle the line, in that I'm neither forthcoming (especially with people I don't know) nor secretive. I don't know about the rest of you, but for me, a good conversation can put an entirely different spin on the day. Above and beyond that, a necessary conversation, if finally out in the open and held with the right person, can put a different spin on your life. I tend to bottle those sorts of conversations up, and either bury them in my brain, or have them in a "once-and-for-all" throwdown. I've been engaging more in the latter behavior these days, and it makes me much happier. Sure, it can be scary to have a "what are the two of us doing" conversation, but no matter the outcome ("We're doing what we do. Stop worrying.") I just feel 100% better about everything. I don't know why I didn't realize this years ago. Perhaps it's more dependent on the person you're talking to than I think, and I'm just lucky that my recent experiences have been with someone I'm very in tune with. Just getting things off your chest, though - as long as it's focused towards the person it concerns, it can be very rewarding no matter what the result.

Heterosexual men and women can't be best friends for very long, and here's why: eventually one or both friends will look either inward (at the friendship) or outward (at another person) to find more. To find, basically, the same qualities that you have in your opposite-sex best friend, only in a person that you can sleep with. You will notice I did say "best friends" and I did that for an important reason. I'm a huge fan of cross-gender friendships, and in fact generally have many more female than male friends. I think having friends of the opposite sex can sometimes be more rewarding, because they give you insight into a thought process that is, at times, highly unlike your own. But you can never get too close, because the complexities of the female/male relationship make it much more susceptible to jealousy and bitterness than most same-sex relationships (and I'm not talking about gay relationships, I mean friendships). With anyone you get along with, to some degree, there will always be that question in the back of your mind that asks "what if...?" In many cases, this question is answered with a truly humorous imaginary relationship that is so awkward and so improbable that it immediately becomes a non-issue. But even if answered with confidence, the question still remains, tucked away, ready to jump out and create conflict when you least expect it. This is not an autobiographical post in the slightest. I mean, it is to the extent that I have friends, but I am lucky enough to be (at least currently) avoiding the pitfalls described above. Hell, I even have a female best friend, but I'm not so naive to think that it will last forever. Perhaps that's the best way of looking at friendships in general. Everybody changes, and just because my female friends have one extra reason to grow apart from me (i.e. they meet a guy who draws them away) that doesn't mean it won't happen to me and my boys. But if you roll with those changes, if you embrace them as they occur and don't expect people to stay locked in a "personality stasis," then you will end up living a happier life, as far as your relationships are concerned. Just one man's opinion, of course. But he has a blog so it must be valuable!

I really have to thank ConLaw, and in particular Prof. Smith, for providing the inspiration for so many of these posts. On to today's! It was offered in today's class that in landmark decisions by the Supreme Court, perhaps the goal of the justices is not to set legal precedent, but rather to provide a calming influence over the culture wars in general. Thus decisions like 2003's Lawrence v. Texas are less about striking down untenable laws like sodomy, and more about injecting a conciliatory decision into the public discourse. The problem, as noted by Prof. Smith, is that because these decisions rely mostly on decrying animus, they may do more to fracture society than to heal it. Such decisions are often wanting for strong legal arguments, so the Court (especially in Lawrence) uses an alternative argument which says those who support such laws do so for immoral and unjust reasons. Any "legitimate" reasons for such laws are pretextual in nature and, at the end of the day, the only reason to have them is to discriminate against a politically unpopular class of people. While this is an interesting argument, it relies on a proposition that I'm not sure I totally agree with. That proposition is that society is more fractured and polarized than ever before - hence the Court must exert a stabilizing influence to keep the polarization from completely tearing us apart. But are people really more ideologically separate than earlier in the nation's history? I think you can only go back as far as the industrial revolution to be fair, but were the 60's really easier than now? Is there a wider gulf separating progressive and conservative, Democrat and Republican, than ever before? I abstain from an opinion, simply because I don't feel like I know enough (nor have I lived long enough) to make a judgment on earlier eras - namely the early 20th century and the 1960's. It certainly feels like people are angrier and more vicious today, but is that because they are or because the media lets us see it more clearly? In completely separate news, only one more week until Spring Break! Not that I'm going anywhere, but it will be nice to have some time off. I should probably work on some papers (since I have four), and if I can stay away from Best Buy's computer game department, I will. I hope nothing cool comes out soon, though...

Well it's all about Kerry v. Bush, isn't it? The field has narrowed, the combatants named (mostly - no VP candidate yet...) and the stage is set for what will probably turn into a knock-down drag-out fight 'till November. My thoughts (because, well, it's my blog)? I'm satisfied with Kerry. The more I consider the alternatives, the more I think it's the best matchup we can hope for, and probably the best chance of beating GWB. Edwards, god bless 'im, has plenty of time left to be President someday. Dean was, for me, too angry and too abrasive. He wouldn't have appealed to that wide swath of America that thinks presidential candidates should be boring and kind and kiss babies. Kucinich obviously didn't see the "You Must Be This Tall To Ride" sign outside the Whitehouse. Clark, that was just a silly idea. Also, as much as I respect all the alternative candidates' opinions, they just weren't pragmatic enough to appeal to a wide margin of voters. So now we have Kerry, and the early anti-Kerry portrait is that he's a waffler, he changes his mind a lot. To me, this is a non-issue, because smart people change their minds. People who are idealogues and zealots have purity of focus, but intelligent people can be persuaded to consider alternative actions. I'm not saying that's why Kerry flip-flops, but to me it's not important. What's more important is that has the right ideas on a number of key issues. He opposes the death penalty, which I was shocked to hear. Edwards doesn't, which is unsurprising from a southerner, but Kerry's vocalized opposition was news to me. Good for him! In conclusion, why not Kerry? He's the most presidential of the original nine, and while he may not be my perfect candidate (no member of urlLink Skull & Bones is) I think he's got a good chance of beating the guy currently holding office. And that's my number one goal for this election.

Classes are over for the semester. The final resounding thump to my skull was administered by Constitutional Law, which featured one of our most lively debates of the year on the question of religion in schools. More specifically, on Evolution vs. Creationism. Although that's not really want I'm going to write about today, I will note that I was a bit taken aback by the number of people that seemed willing to thrown Evolutionary Theory to the wolves just for the sake of not having to deal with Creationism (i.e. "why teach any of it at all?"). So, religion. I've mentioned it before, I believe, but I'm too lazy to go back and find the post and reference it here. Today's class made me wonder: is an organized religion necessary? Is it just a pretext for assigning weight to human rights and morals that we want to live by? Or does it have some deeper purpose, does it legitimately fill a human need that is unfillable by any other means? I grew up in an observant but not intensely devout Catholic family. It has always seemed to me, however, that the day-to-day activities of going to church, praying before meals, and otherwise being tepidly religious obscures the real purpose. If God exists, then (note: I just picked a pronoun, it happens to be male) He's extraordinarily powerful, probably omnipotent, and probably couldn't give a rat's ass what we individuals do here on Earth. Sure, if He's benevolent then He probably thinks it's best we don't go around knocking each other upside the head and running over puppies. But prayer is certainly not going to change anything, since God has no reason at all to randomly intervene in some lives but not others. All that leads me to believe that God, whom I do believe exists in some form, would rather we figure things out for ourselves. Find inner strength, depend on friends and family, but for His sake don't look to the heavens for some kind of Divine Inspiration. Perhaps God really is just a tool to explain the unexplained and reason with the unknown. Maybe He exists to give us more self-confidence, to lend credence to inspirations that are wholly human in origin, but seem so insightful that we must attribute them to a greater omnipotent force. On the other hand, I also sort of believe in demons, evil, and exorcisms, and how that fits in to the idea of God as a benevolent and all-powerful force, I'm not sure. Maybe that's my own need to believe in something unexplained, since in most other aspects I'm a fairly concrete I'll-believe-it-when-I-see-it kind of guy. Or maybe I just watch too much TV.

Background: In ConLaw today, we learned that most of the strength behind the separation of church and state comes from Everson v. Board of Education , which in turn bases modern religion/government interaction on a series of events that occurred in Virginia 200 years ago. In short, Virginia was a trailblazer at the time, being the first state to erect a real, meaningful wall between church and state operations. Although I felt a momentary bit of pride -- it's not every day that my home state is brought up in a California law school class -- I also realized it was probably the most progressive thing Virginia ever did. And it was centuries ago. Today, Virginia is like a host of other states that have unique geographic divisions that are reflected onto the psyche of the populous. California has its North vs. South debate (which is really San Francisco vs. Los Angeles), and it also seems to have a Coast vs. Inland thing. I haven't been here long enough to figure out that second one. New York has its NYC vs. Everywhere Else, even Michigan has a Upper vs. Lower Peninsula thing. Not to be left out, Virginia has Northern Virginia vs. The Rest of the State. Virginia, when you mention to people who aren't from the east coast, is often imagined much like Mississippi, Alabama, and South Carolina. This may be because of Virginia's rich history as the preeminent southern state -- after all, it was the seat of the Confederacy. But nobody from the D.C. area looks at Virginia this way, because the D.C. area is metropolitan. I went to school in southwest Virginia, however, and I can tell you that the rest of Virginia harbors a deep resentment towards NoVA. Justified to some degree because NoVA receives the bulk of any funding (though they also pay most of the taxes, but hey), the resentment is mutual because of the aforementioned "image problem" that Virginia has. In the end, the northerners hate the southerners because they make the country think we're bumpkins. The southerners hate the northerners because most Virginians ARE hicks, and their tax money usually goes to NoVA. Personally, I like both sides. I like the low bar that people set when they hear that I was born in Virginia, because it gives me a chance to detect any perceived stereotypes in those that I meet. But I also like being from a metropolis that rivals the greatest cities in the world. Perhaps that makes me less apologetic about my status as a Virginian, but my lack of embarrassment may also stem from the fact that I don't assign much weight to a person's state of origin. But that's a post for another day.

I'm a pretty cynical guy, in some ways. Also have a strong pessimistic streak and am quite self-deprecating, but lets just stick with the cynicism for now. But for just a moment, I'd like to decynicize (not a word!) and mention some things. Everybody hates bad drivers. Bad drivers are everywhere, they have their heads in their asses and resoundly suck. But you know what? When YOU'RE on the phone, or jabbering away with a friend, and driving - you're the bad driver. You make the mistake of being in the wrong lane to turn, or not going the speed limit. So lighten up a little, okay? The world is not going to hell just because somebody cut you off. Between watching episodes of " urlLink I Want a Famous Face " on MTV and " urlLink The Swan " on FOX, I'm fairly certain I've lost all my respect for humanity. The first show's premise is "Hey look at these complete numbnut kids we've found, let's document their horrific journey to make themselves look like a celebrity!" If that goal were accomplished through mere warddrobe and make-up alterations (wasn't there a similarly-premised show on MTV a while back?) it would just be fluff TV. Instead, these vacuum-brained people actually go through thousands of dollars of cosmetic surgery, getting implants and suctions and various other procedures. In the end, they look nothing like the celebrity they idolize. If I were famous, I would pay these people NOT to look like me. The Swan's premise, from what I've seen, is that ugly people suck and are often so ugly that not even copious amounts of training and surgery can change that. Two women enter at the beginning of each episode, and at the end they basically tell one of them "Guess what? You're still too ugly to be on this show. Via con dios!" If that isn't a depressingly accurate depiction of our society, I'll move to Canada. The impetus behind this post was, of course, watching some complete nimrod get huge breasts so that she could pose for Playboy and look more like Pamela Anderson. Nevermind that she was perfectly attractive already. The best part was when Playboy said they weren't really looking for the big-boob thing anymore, but thanks! Cosmetic surgery is stupid. Unless it's to correct a major physical defect (in which case it's more accurately termed reconstructive surgery, I think) you need to stay the hell away from it. Getting a mole removed or something "lifted" isn't the worst thing in the world, but getting ANYTHING implanted is just plain nuts. Just Say No, kids.

The Friday Five is lame this week (sad, considering the 2-week hiatus it was just on) so instead, you get my thoughts on dating. Everyone talks about what they want in a mate. "She has to be as smart as me" or "He has to be confident" et cetera. While it's good to know what you want out of a relationship, the real key (at least in my opinion) is knowing when to drop someone who is NOT living up to your expectations. If you're going to make lists about the perfect mate, especially urlLink lists that are perfectly reasonable - shouldn't you actually DEMAND those things when you actually meet a real person? (Editor's Note: the link goes to an example, not a target of this post) Unfortunately, I think women are the ones who fail to follow through on this claim. Men, for all their many failings, rarely put up with women who don't meet whatever level of performance they've imposed. Women, on the other hand, often mistakenly believe that they can change a person. Putting aside the fact that the only real change in a person must come from within (a blog post for another day), this leaves many women in relationships with guys who don't meet even HALF the "requirements" they would list if asked. Perhaps it's a self-esteem thing. The "he might be the only one who will put up with me" syndrome that many women (and some men) are afflicted with. And yes, there's also love, which I don't discount. But true love will not be found with someone who is sub-par. You may be infatuated with, or simply attracted to someone who is no good, but don't use love as an excuse for staying in a relationship with a complete loser. The only way men will ever step up and become better men is if they realize that they can no longer behave like bumps on a log and still hang on to their women. When women demand better, men will start getting better, and we'll all win. But if women keep putting up with the shit men give them, men will never change. And men will always have more power in that situation, so it'd also be better for feminism and society if that changed, as well. Recognize when you're in a bad thing. Recognize it objectively, and get out. Listen to friends and family that you trust to give you an honest opinion. Don't balance unfairly -- "Sure he never takes me out or remembers my birthday, but he bought me flowers once for no reason!" is a good example of poor justification. And don't reward bad behavior by accepting it.

For an as-yet undiscovered reason, I am in a fairly solid financial situation this semester. I haven't really determined why, because even accounting for parental generosity, I'd still be in okay shape. Note : Okay shape, for those of you who have jobs, means I can pay rent - nothing more. I'm not buying yachts or TVs (or even movies), I'm just not going to have to ask for much, if any, help from the parents this summer. But the lack of financial stress--other than that looming $140,000 debt I have attached to my person as of next May--has given me a moment to consider my overall views on money. My complete disclosure before saying anything, of course, is that I've never been destitute and my family is comfortably upper-middle-class, at least nowadays. When I have money, I spend it. I save it when something tells me I should (i.e. to afford vacations, or presumably when children are born to save for college) but otherwise, I have no attachment whatsoever to seeing lots of cash in my bank account. People don't often ask me for money, especially now that I'm living fat off the government, but when they do I've almost always given them whatever I could. I don't give out loans, though; approximately 90% of any financial assistance I've ever given has been given without a plea for repayment. Along those lines, aside from large rent-paying checks or outright "gifts" because of dire straits, most of what I do is pay for stuff. I don't mind picking up a check, if I can, especially when it's dinner for two or a movie or just... whatever. I wouldn't call it chivalry, because although it occurs with my female friends more often, that's simply because I have more female friends. In truth, I'm not sure why I operate that way, because at this point it's second nature. I certainly don't keep track of what I pay for (I mean, other than for my own bookkeeping purposes) so it's not about reciprocity either. I guess in the end my point is this: save when necessary, but otherwise, don't be such a cheap bastard. Really, this applies to things beyond money (love, friendship, volunteering) but people seem to get super worked up about cash most of all. It's only temporary, and as long as you remain smart--no giving away your kid's orthodonture fund--it's a much less anxious way to live. Oh, and stop asking for repayments of loans. If you give someone money, and you don't specifically sign a document detailing repayment, then when they don't repay you, just remember that for next time and call it a day. If it the money was that important to you, you should have been more careful to detail the terms of the transaction--but since you didn't, let it go.

I find it curious that a number of people see reading a person's blog as a small invasion of privacy. Even curiouser, I get almost angry when I hear other bloggers complain about people reading/commenting on their blogs. I've even seen posts like "...and whoever it is that visits my blog from Alabama, get out! If you're not my friend you shouldn't be here!" People, people. It's the Internet - you can't pick and choose your visitors if you don't put up some kind of password. If you want a private, intimate website that only a select few can find and read, then creating a blog is that absolute wrong way to go about it. Not only is it asinine, it goes against the entire point of having weblogs. Whether you comment on the news like some, or on your personal life, or you just write for writing's sake - the point isn't to keep it to yourself. But on the other side of the blogging coin, I find it silly when people (even friends!) stumble over my blog and then actually feel bad about reading it. Granted, such people aren't very accustomed to the idea of blogs (living under a rock, eh?) but I would give no apologies if I found someone's blog and read it. None. Even if they claimed it was private (see above). Because if you're going to put something out there, you have a responsibility to not get yer undies in a twist when "the wrong people" find it, read it, and react to it. That's why I write in general terms, with first names only, and don't talk about too many person-specific feelings. It's not because I don't have 'em, it's because This Blog is supposed to be egalitarian in function. My parents and sisters read it, as do a couple ex-girlfriends, as do a couple never-were-girlfriends, as do friends. If something I write offends one of those groups, then I take full responsibility (well, for offending, not for whether they SHOULD have been offended). I would never tell someone to stop reading it, as that would be the height of hypocrisy. Welcome, one and all!

If you're not familiar with Buffy, it's the episode where her mom dies, not from supernatural means (as is how most people on Buffy meet their untimely demise) but rather from an aneurysm. I won't go into specifics, but it's quite possibly the most moving, realistic, and well-shot hour of television that I've ever seen. (EDITOR'S NOTE: I'm still sure that something like this exists in physics, but it's also called the Hawthorne Effect in sociology, wherein "individual behaviors may be altered because they know they are being studied.") As has also been mentioned previously, I urlLink undertook some changes to "jettison" certain parts of my life that seemed overly complex or unhealthy. The problem with that is, I don't need any more time for quiet self-realization. I do plenty of introspection during even my busiest times, and if there's one thing I don't need more of, it's time to think. In the end, I will (in my third internal reference, yikes) try to urlLink recapture some of my hobbies and interests, such as piano, crossword puzzles, and the destabilization of post-industrialization South American economies. It'll be a summer to remember, I guarantee. Also, you'll like the way you look, I guarantee it.

Read urlLink this article on Slate, by the smartest legal analyst writing today. The real problem is that there are really only three arguments against gay marriage: One is rooted in entirely God's preferenceswhich have little bearing on Equal Protection or Due Process doctrine, as far as I can tell. The second cites inconclusive research on its negative effects on children. The backup is the slippery slope jeremiad, which seems to pass for a legal argument, at least on cable TV. But fear of the slippery slope alone is not a sufficient justification for doing the wrong thing in any individual case. Damn skippy it's not. I've never found the "slippery slope" argument to be a very valid concern in ANY area of law, and it's cited in many, many areas of law. It was argued during desegregation and the civil rights movement, and clearly THAT was a valid concern (note sarcasm denoted by all-caps writing). The article notes that there are some valid, notable concerns with a "slippery slope" metaphor, but also correctly labels it as just that - a metaphor, not a sound legal principle. I'm off to turn in my papers, and to grant sweet release to this semester in full.

Yesterday, we taught the first round of new Law Review members how to cite-check so that they can get started on it this summer. The new folk are all 1L's who placed in the top 5% of the class after fall semester was over, so clearly they're pretty good at schoolwork. What they're also good at, however, is being stressed-out piles of neuroses. Because they're all top of the class, a large number of them are also super-involved in everything and quite busy. Summer jobs, clerkships, research assistants, etc. While most of them rightfully embrace being on Law Review, some are so... "harried" at this point that they actually consider declining it. Declining Law Review membership is like being an independent filmmaker who spends a year making a really good movie, and then declines an Oscar nomination because they're "too busy to handle it." And no, I don't mean the Sean Penn-types who avoid it for moral or political reasons. It's a lot of work, everybody knows that. But you can't get a higher honor in law school, other than whatever cum laude crap they may hand out at graduation. I'm lucky as hell that I managed to write on, so perhaps I'm biased--I actually had to actively try to get on Law Review, whereas the others are simply awarded membership based on grades. Some of the Board mentioned yesterday that some schools have write-on only law reviews, and I'm not quite sure whether that's a good idea or not. On the one hand, law review is heavily writing-oriented, so it makes sense. But to grade on, you have to have some writing competence so it's not like that unrelated. It also provides a mix of personality types when you have both write-ons and grade-ons. I'm not even in the top 50% of my class (last time I checked, it was close, but not quite) so I'm sure I bring a different point of view to the proceedings. Anyway, if you're on Law Review, don't be a wuss and quit. Even if you don't care about the "honor", realize that any employer who sees you're high ranking in the class will question why you declined to join, and the "it was a lot of work" answer--no matter how legitimate it was at the time--is going to make you sound really lame.

Time to vent. I saw Troy this afternoon, and it was entertaining although not "good" in the classic sense of the word. Too many liberties taken with the Iliad for my tastes, even if it's understandable given that the filmmakers wanted to remove the gods from the story. What also irked me, though, were the gratuitous shots of a half-naked Brad Pitt. I'm all for nudity if it fits the story, and hey sometimes even when it doesn't. But the movies that use it excessively are bad, almost across the board. A good movie with nakedness doesn't overuse it, it just uses it as necessary - see urlLink American Beauty for an example, in my opinion. What really annoys me, however, is not gratuitous skin (after all, there is far more female skin in the movies), but it's the fact that for some reason, women feel obliged or even liberated in ogling Brad Pitt-type actors, but when men do the same--often much more subtly--we're branded as pigs. This is unfair, and it pisses me off. Not because I'm clamoring to vocally express my appreciation for the female form, but because even if I wanted to I'd catch a load of crap for it. Maybe for good reason - women have lots of body image issues, and perhaps seeing guys slobbering over rail-thin actresses doesn't help. But isn't it hypocritical to demand guys behave one way, and then turn around and act just as bad (worse, I would say)? Granted, men may not have as many body image issues, but is that really the point? If women want to be taken seriously, and if you believe that an impediment to that is that our culture unfairly emphasizes looks over substance, shouldn't both sexes strive to look beyond that? I know, movies are just movies. But swooning over Brad Pitt is just one example, women swoon over real life guys all the time. I just think that those who do so should relinquish the right to even mutter under their breath when guys do the same. It occurs to me that I'm in a pretty hefty bad mood, and have been for a couple days, so maybe this is all just me be angry at something else. Take it with a grain of salt, then.

This country, and perhaps the world, needs a new period of enlightenment. A new renaissance period, where ideas are praised and ignorance is no longer something to be proud of. The first step would be to hold those who are intelligent and creative in high regard. This is a problem not only in politics (I wouldn't be the first, second, or even 1 millionth person to note that our President is a detached and disinterested dullard) but also in celebrity. Hollywood has a knack for pandering to the lowest common denominator, but when was the last time that you heard of someone simply because they were brilliant in their field? The last "literary star" to really sweep the nation was J.K. Rowling. I have nothing against Ms. Rowling, and I think the Harry Potter books are quite entertaining, but they're not masterpieces. Still, they're the closest thing we've got to a step in the right direction, for the singular reason that they've encouraged a generation of kids to read. We need another "Quiz Show" phenomenon. Not with the scandal part, of course, but rather the part that made America tune in to see people who weren't pretending to be less intelligent than they are. We need an "American Idol" for physics or art, not music. We're pretty well covered in the bad pop-music department, so I'm not sure why discovering more bad pop talent should be a priority. None of this will happen until Americans start believing they should, and can, be better. Not this "fat dumb and happy" mentality that currently occupies the minds of a majority of Americans. And lest you think otherwise, this isn't an attack against only the traditionally ignorant - conservatives. Liberals who refuse to see other points of view and constantly rail against issues that they don't fully understand (I'm looking at you, WTO protestors) are just as bad. I can't think of an eloquent way to end this post, so I'll just stop typing. I should be studying, anyhow.

Attention dastardly fellows: I know you're not very smart. If you were, you probably wouldn't be a criminal. The sad truth of the Real World (actual, not MTV-version) is that crimes are very hard to pull off successfully, and the penalty for failing is often far more severe than the benefits you might reap. Armed robbery for $150 in cash? How about 20 years in prison instead! That being said, my Criminal Procedure class has armed with me with a few very simple, fairly obvious (to some, at least) rules that the criminal element should live by. 1. Do not consent to anything. The police will ask if they can--don't let them. Don't let them search your car, house, purse, body cavities, or anything else you might have. Refusal to consent is not a crime, and if the police have the power to search without your approval, they will. It cannot hurt unless you're innocent and you have somewhere to be. But if you're a pothead and you can't remember if you left drugs in the trunk, do not say "sure" when the cops ask to look . The temptation to seem easy-going and like you have nothing to hide should be fought, unless you really do have nothing to hide. 2. Do not run. Running, when combined with other factors, can make your actions rise to the level of reasonable suspicion. Other factors can include "being in a high crime area" so those of you in such places should stick to indoor gyms when you jog. Running is viewed suspiciously; always walk when you're trying to get away. That is unless the cops already have enough to arrest you; in that case you should run your ass off. 3. Do not give access to evidence of your misdeeds to third parties. If you robbed a bank, don't give your disguise to your mom for the laundry. If you sell heroin out of your backpack, don't ask your friend to hold it while you go out to get a hamburger. They will give your stuff to the police if asked . Same goes for roommates, officemates, wives, husbands, kids above a certain age and possibly even the mailman.* *kids below about 10 aren't usually able to consent to access because they're too young. Also, I was kidding about the mailman, unless you gave him a key to the house. Now, let's go out there and make Cops more entertaining for everyone who watches.

The first time I got into a fight (other than little wrestling scraps as a boy) was in the 8th grade. Roberto Sanchez was the villain's name, and he tormented me the entire year. He was the typical bully--not very smart, big for his age, and more than a little cruel. After picking on me mercilessly for 2 semesters of junior high, I snapped. Waiting behind the backstop during a mandatory softball game in gym, I of course found myself on the same team as Roberto. He grew bored with making fun of the batters (who were, of course, on his team; another sign of his poor socialization skills) and decided to put me in a headlock. The impromptu rules of the headlock were that I had to say I was a "faggot" to (in theory) secure my release. This was a common sport, often alternating "say you like boys" or "cry like a girl" as the secret phrase, probably depending on what Roberto had for breakfast that morning. But by the end of junior high, I had had enough. I usually resisted until he let go (I didn't want to say I cried like a girl if I wasn't even going to cry), but this time I hit him in the head so that he'd let go. I wasn't very big at the time but he let go and as I tried to punch him, he sort of laughed at me. But then, I got in a good shot to his face. He stopped laughing and decided to beat me into oblivion. Fortunately for my physical health, our gym teacher had started running to break up the fight as soon as it started, and at that moment arrived and literally checked Robert with one arm, knocking him down. I've wondered since then if that wasn't excessive force, when you consider that Mr. Frasier was a 6 foot 200 lb. 29-year-old gym teacher and Roberto, though terrifying to other 13-year-olds, was still just a kid. But it became the stuff of legend ("Did you hear how Frasier totally kicked Roberto's ass?") as did the copious swearing that issued forth as I hammered Roberto with my ineffective fists of fury. Apparently, I can cuss a blue streak. I don't remember because I was in such a rage, so most of the specifics escape me (parts of this story are compiled from eyewitness accounts). I've been fortunate to avoid most (but not all) fights as I got older, usually by avoiding people who try and fight with me. But that first one stays with you. I'm way bigger than Roberto now. And my rap sheet is probably shorter. Criminal bastard.

I'm a liberal. It would not be terribly far off the mark to call me a bleeding-heart, tree-hugging pinko, except that I don't hug trees with any sort of regularity. I don't believe in capital punishment, draconian drug sentencing, restrictions on abortion or gay rights, and a litany of other conservative ideals that will no doubt keep my soul from entering the kingdom of heaven when I pass beyond this mortal coil. But Michael Moore is starting to irritate the bejesus out of me. I'm so anti-Bush I can't see straight, but Moore is getting to be so full of himself that he bugs even me. Case in point: his repeated threats to sue anybody who trashes Fahrenheit 9/11, using defamation or slander laws. First of all, if people say the movie sucks you can't do a damn thing. That's not what libel law is meant to restrict. Only people who make outright false claims (like "Moore is a pedophilic Satan-worshipper") can even begin to be prosecuted, and even then if it's said in any sort of op/ed format (I'm looking at you, Wall Street Journal) it's simply opinion. So why is Moore saying all this? Because he's annoying. And of course I don't mean the local base-ball team. Some of the earliest memories I have of my dad are outdoor memories. Every time it would rain (in Virginia, it happens frequently) he would march us outside to "follow the water" as it rushed down the street towards the creeks and/or storm drains. Dad tried to pass this off as one of the many quirky habits of a civil engineer, but I think it had more to do with just being a kid again. Playing in a summer rain, when it's far too warm to catch your death, and after the most serious lightning had passed on (but not completely, because the occasional crack of thunder livened up any outing) will stick in my head for the rest of my life. It's a good memory, one I hope to repeat with my own kids if I haven't gone all cat's cradle and missed their formative years due to a hour-intensive attorney job. Something about my generally lazy nature tells me that the job won't be much of an obstacle. More likely it will be finding a will pair of ovaries to help with the procreation. Single guys who play too many computer games are rarely offered the adoptive opportunities given to "normal" couples. And by normal I mean "responsible and not impoverished."

Isn't it weird that the words "opened" and "closed" can both be used to mean a state of being (i.e. that package is "opened" or "closed") but "open" and "close" cannot? You can still say "that package is open" but you can't say "that package is close" unless you're using "close" to mean nearby. But I'm not, I mean it as in the condition of a sealed container. Why do we spell those two words the same way, anyhow? "Close" (your books, class) and "close" (to someone you love) aren't remotely related, and it must seem awfully confusing to those who are learning English as a second language. Now that I've written the word "close" like eight times, it's starting to look surreal and not at all correct. Like when I write "tear" and mean something that falls from your eye instead of something you do to paper--that doesn't seem right at ALL. Stop the madness!

Warning: God-related entry not for the faint of faith. I believe in God, I really do. At least, I think I do. I believe in something out there that is more powerful than we insignificant humans, and if it turns out to be God then I will jump onboard his bandwagon. It seems like there are two components to organized religion, faith and worship. They are at opposite ends of the spectrum, as I see it, because faith is impossible to fake, while worship ridiculously easy to fake. You can't pretend, at least internally, to believe something that you don't. Sure you can say you believe to others, but ultimately faith is an internally set mechanism. Worship, on the other hand, is all outward. We go to church, we praise the Lord our God and his son Jesus or Buddha or possibly that Six-Armed Fellow (Vishnu?) but since faith is in our hearts, what does worship matter? I think it matter not at all. Consider this: God, if It exists (and we'll assume It does for purposes of this blog entry), created everything, including mankind. Why did he do this? The only thing man can give to God is praise, but why would God need praise? For that matter, since the only thing we can offer is worship, that would mean that God (being all-knowing) created mankind for the sole purpose of having worshippers. This creates (in my mind) a problem; why should we, as free-willed individuals, worship something that created us only so that we would worship It? What kind of all-powerful being made of love and happiness requires devotion? Creating an entire universe so that somebody will pay attention to you seems to be the height of narcissism, or egocentricity. Since the idea of an egotistical God is rather absurd, I think it must mean that worship in almost all of its forms--church building, hymn singing, any sort of sacramental endeavor--is rather pointless unless it is done solely to affirm your faith. Some (many, perhaps) would argue that of course that's the whole reason we have institutional religion: to help people get in touch with their faith. To those people I say maybe once that was true, but today private worship is discouraged, and that makes no sense. If your heart is full of faith in God, why must you prove your love to Him/Her by sitting in uncomfortable pews and singing mostly tuneless hymns? Why must you attend church at all, unless you find it entertaining? Maybe I'm off base. Maybe faith and worship are more intertwined than I believe. A further exploration of the meaning of faith is probably in order, but I've work to do so that will have to wait until another day when I'm feeling particularly theological. Or maybe I should say "blasphemous and pretentious."

I've decided I'm done with Internet-arranged dating. Match.com, Spring Street Networks, Yahoo Personals, eHarmony (I only used two, but I know people who've used all these) -- they're all well and good, but they're not going to give me what I'm looking for. What I've realized is that the criteria used by these websites to match you with other people, or even to just display in a profile, is largely irrelevant to a meaningful relationship. Favorite book? Sure, that's interesting, but how many people have fallen in love because they share a passion for Ayn Rand? The questions are designed to find people with similar interests, but if you're really looking for someone, it doesn't matter what those interests are. I've never dated ANYONE who had even half the same interests as me. We've differed on books, music, television, movies, politics, art, the existences of a higher being, whether fried chicken is good... but what mattered was that intangible quality that you cannot find listed in an online profile. This doesn't mean online dating is useless, though. If you just want to "get out there" and go on some dates, then it's definitely a good tool. Or, if it's your bag, I would imagine it's an easy way to find casual sex that's a few steps up from drunkenly picking up/getting picked up at a club. But if you're looking for something that goes deeper (and it seems that at some point, most people are), you've just got to live your life, and take your opportunities where they appear.

When faced with contradicting sentiment from someone, how do you know what's real - their actions, or their words? Someone can say lovely things but fail to act in a similar manner, whereas someone else can say nothing but find a way to always show up when you need them. Is one more indicative of actual feeling than the other? In one man's opinion (mine), yes. Absolutely yes. This goes for all kinds of relationships, too - familial, friendships, etc. The thing about words is that they're easy to say. Some people are quite gifted in spinning a tale of epic love, and at the time they may actually mean what they say. But there's a reason they say that "talk is cheap," and that's because actions aren't. Actions require forethought; you've got to think about the person when they're not around, because action (usually) requires planning. Talking requires no planning, however, so those who are even marginally skilled at stringing together sentences can come up with the right words to defuse a situation on the fly. That's why actions mean more than words. Obviously, some people can mean what they say and say what they mean. But if they don't act to back those words up, then what they say is hollow and shouldn't be given any credit for simple platitudes. This may seem obvious to many people, but when you're actually in a situation, whether it's with a best friend, girlfriend, or parent, it can be difficult to see. But we all know, instinctively, when someone isn't living up to their stated intentions. What makes it hard to fix is the fact that, when it is pointed out that Person A isn't acting how Person B thinks they should, they have to talk about the situation. And Person A can easily talk their way out of the problem, yet remain unchanged when it comes to acting differently. When it all comes together, he or she will act and speak off the same page, and that's when you can take the words to heart.

The 4th amendment prohibits search and seizure without a warrant. It is a basic tenet of the Constitution and a staple of criminal procedure that the government has no right to rifle through your things or put you in custody without probable cause. There are many exceptions or qualifications to the 4th Amendment (like exigent circumstances), but one of the most interesting related issues is the exclusion of evidence obtained in a search that violates the 4th. It may seem obvious to most people that if finding the evidence violated the Constitution, using the evidence in court to prosecute is also prohibited. But in fact, Congress and the Courts have come dangerously close to removing that exclusionary rule from use and replacing it with a monetary award. That is, if your house is searched without a warrant or probable cause, and they find 50 lbs. of cocaine, they can use it against you in a criminal trial but would be liable to you in civil court for something like $10,000. Fortunately, that is not the current lawprosecutors simply cannot use evidence obtained illegally. Many people object to this because it applies only to criminals (it wouldn't be evidence against you if you committed no crime) and hampers effective prosecution. Thats why in 1995, Congress tried to pass a law removing the rule and inserting monetary damages. The thought was that it would create the same, and perhaps a greater, deterrent effect and police still wouldn't search and seize without warrants because theyd have to pay. Which rather long-windedly brings me to my point. If such a law were passed, I dont think it would have nearly as much of a deterrent effect as Congress might suppose. Police would use covert surveillance anytime and anywhere they wished, without need for any suspicion or warrant, and would only move to obtain evidence when the crime it indicated was severe enough to warrant paying for the illegal search. But if you dont have evidence of a crime in your house, and the police are bugging you, when will you initiate a civil suit? When would you even know youd been searched? Technology would allow widespread abuse of police power and most people would never even know they were being watched. Youd only find out when the police came to arrest you and confiscate the evidence, and then a $10,000 award seems awfully insignificant when compared to the prison sentence you may be receiving.

I can see the allure of an anonymous blog sometimes, I really can. It's an interesting phenomenon that the best blogs are often "outed" by their own outstandingness. urlLink Fish , for example, is grappling with the problem of being anonymous-no-more, and what that means for her blog. The anonymous blog gives you greater freedom to speak your mind--whether by giving salacious and licentious details about dating, or by lambasting friends and relatives for idiotic behavior. But as with any good story, the devil is in the details, and an anonymous blog can only give so many. For instance, for anything I say to be relevant, you'd have to know I was in San Diego and at law school. That immediately limits me to one of about 1000 people, give or take. If I were to rant about undergrads or heavy tuition, you'd know I was at USD, and simple arithmetic would probable tell you I'm going into my third year of school here. My point is, even had I attempted to stay anonymous, it wouldn't be hard to get a fairly good idea of who I am. And if a friend stumbled upon the page, well they'd probably know me in an instant. The only way to prevent being discovered would be to keep readership very low and very non-local, and that's just plain difficult (and counterintuitive--don't we bloggers WANT readers?) The alternative, which I readily embrace, is to give up the urge to disclose the most titillating details of my life, and in return I get to tell my friends and family about the blog. It's a trade-off I sometimes regret, but at the end of the day I find it more worthwhile. And hey, if I ever do have the need to tell some other stories, I can always start a new blog. Not that I would tell YOU people.
