The first time I remember noticing girls--and by noticing, I mean beyond the fact that they were similar to me except most had longer hair and played with lamer toys--was sometime in grade school. A bunch of the girls had formed a club wherein they pretended they were unicorns and chased the boys they liked or, failing the appearance of one of those, any boy who would run. As boys, we just wanted to play tag and be left to our own dirt-throwing devices, but the girls routinely ended every game of tag early by swooping in and chasing one or more of the players away. To this day, I'm not really sure why unicorns would chase 9-year-olds, but at the time it made sense (to the girls). But regardless as to the logic behind their actions, it became my first experience with the confusing emotions that appear whenever a member of the opposite sex is present. I wanted to be left alone, to play tag or to throw rocks at the wall or to do whatever it is that 9-year-old boys do at recess. But at the same time, I noticed my first real feelings of jealousy when the other boys were picked and chased and I was left unharassed. Sure I didn't want to be chased, except that maybe I sort of did. Finally, one day, they descended on me and I cursed them and ran (like we all did) both annoyed and exhilirated at the same time. Little did I know that, with regards to women, this would be only the first of many times that I would experience both feelings simultaneously. In 3rd or 4th or 5th grade, one of the girls at my school actually started liking me. She sent me notes and love letters that said things like "I caught myself staring at you during the movie about Noah's Ark" (Catholic school) and "If you want to be boyfriend/girlfriend, just say 'green' and if not say 'red'." She was one of the quiet, dorky girls that I would eventually come to appreciate but, at the time, did not. I was already a magnet for teasing (unruly hair and hideous glasses will do that to a lad) and being seen with her would only escalate my daily torture. I turned her down ("Red. I'm sorry.") and went to play with my Transformers in the another room. Sadly, while I have come to appreciate the brainy, interesting type, that type has stopped appreciating me. I'm not sure where I lost my credibility as the brooding, quiet guy, but now that the tables have turned, I find myself unable to meet the right kind of person. I'm too sociable for the angst-ridden girls, and too angst-ridden for the sociable girls. It was all alot easier when you could tell a girl liked you by how loudly she screamed as she chased you through the yard at recess.

We have this one article for the next issue that I affectionately think of as the Article from Hell. Or Dis, or Hades, or whatever suits your fancy. It came into the editing process with zero footnotes (as if the author had never heard of a law review article before) and has ever since been a headache and a half. As I've attempted to boringly explain before, law review articles are known for two things: content and corroboration. You can't just claim things left and right without backing your stuff up--I mean, this isn't journalism or public relations. That's why articles have footnotes. A standard, long law review article will have between 150 and 200 of them, all of which must be verified for correctness (at least in theory) before we will publish the article. So an article without footnotes is either really, really short (and completely opinion, which is extremely rare) or really, really badly put together. The content may be sterling, but without proper citing even the best ideas in the world are worthless. You've got to show your work, people! Anyway, this article has been a headache. It's also tough because it concerns foreign law and thus references numerous books that are in another language. This, of course, makes cite-checking impossible to hicks like me that can only (barely) speak English. Well, and a little French. And I can count to ten in Spanish. And I can say "No" in like 5 languages (hint: it's usually something starting with "N"). This is what I've been up to, and why my blog is boring. My actual life is boring too. Today is slightly different, as I am off to help Hilary move, again. She has managed to pick what the weather guy is calling "the height of our heat wave" so that should be loads of fun. Luckily she is also poor and owns very little actual stuff.

It turns out you have your own urlLink self-appointed protector , standing vigilant against the obvious danger inherent in having any Muslim person within a 500-mile radius. He doesn't even try to hide his complete disdain for the entire religion. As one entry notes, Internet terrorists may not have stolen GWU's server space, but rather since "10% of the student population... is Muslim. I wouldn't be surprised if the videos were posted using IDs and passwords issued by GWU." While I wouldn't be surprised if one or two students were involved (because who knows) implying that the entire Muslim student body at GW is part of a terrorist plot is going more than too far. He also says that because the security company hired by Dulles employs many Muslims, they weren't as "on guard" as they should have been on 9/11. I'm sorry, could that link be any MORE attenuated? Taken to its logical end, that means only white Republicans should be hired for any security job, because the mere presence of "dangerous minorities" would dull the super-keen senses of those on guard. It's easy to start blaming an entire group of people for the actions of one particular subgroup, and the reason it's easy is because doing so requires little adherence to common sense or reality. Muslims are, like every religion, a diverse group. There are nuts--just like in Christianity and Judaism--and there are normal folk. Instead of focusing our security on a hugely impractical swath of people, let's look for those who are actually terrorists . Then, we avoid violating rights and defaming the innocent, yet we still get to save lives! I am by no means a terrorist sympathizer. But I think we should find, arrest, or kill only the people responsible for terrorist actions, not their friends, families, acquaintances, mail carriers, or block captains. Yeah, it's tougher to cast a smaller net, but it's no use casting a large one. There's far too much unhelpful junk to sift through.
